<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Thermochemistry</div>
Phase changes from solid → liquid → gas are <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""endothermic"" data-ordinal=""1"">[endothermic or exothermic]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Thermochemistry</div>
    Phase changes from solid → liquid → gas are <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">endothermic</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Gases have more heat energy than liquids and&nbsp;liquids have more heat energy than solids</div><div><br /></div><div><img src=""Phase Changes.png"" /></div><div><br /></div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0cUK4jcAEaU"">YouTube Link</a></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Thermochemistry</div>
Phase changes from gas → liquid → solid are <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""exothermic"" data-ordinal=""1"">[endothermic or exothermic]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Thermochemistry</div>
    Phase changes from gas → liquid → solid are <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">exothermic</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>These&nbsp;reactions <u>release</u> heat energy</div><div><br /></div><div><div><img src=""Phase Changes.png"" /></div><div><br /></div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0cUK4jcAEaU"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::Carbohydrates</div>
The <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""D&#x20;and&#x20;L&#x20;system"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the convention that is used to designate the configurations of&nbsp;<i>chiral carbons</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::Carbohydrates</div>
    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">D and L system</span> is the convention that is used to designate the configurations of&nbsp;<i>chiral carbons</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Based on the D- and L- forms of <i>glyceraldehyde</i><br></div><div><br></div><div>Nearly all carbohydrates in&nbsp;nature are in the <u>D-configuration</u><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""D and L System (1).jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://chem.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/Organic_Chemistry/Book:_Basic_Principles_of_Organic_Chemistry_(Roberts_and_Caserio)/19:_More_on_Stereochemistry/19.05:_Absolute_And_Relative_Configuration"">Chem Libre Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::Carbohydrates</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Carbohydrates"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are&nbsp;""<u>hydrates of carbon</u>""
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::Carbohydrates</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Carbohydrates</span> are&nbsp;""<u>hydrates of carbon</u>""
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>
<div><div>Usually have the formula&nbsp;<b>C<sub>m</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>n</sub></b></div></div><div><br></div><div>Example: Glucose is&nbsp;<b>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub></b></div><div><br></div><div>H:O ratio is usually 2:1 due to the ""hydration"" with H<sub>2</sub>O</div><div><br></div><div>Glucose:</div><div><img src=""Glucose.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mUo4c2f9rpI"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::Carbohydrates</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Enantiomers"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are stereoisomers that are&nbsp;non-superimposable&nbsp;and&nbsp;<u>are</u> <u>mirror images</u>&nbsp;of each other
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::Carbohydrates</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Enantiomers</span> are stereoisomers that are&nbsp;non-superimposable&nbsp;and&nbsp;<u>are</u> <u>mirror images</u>&nbsp;of each other
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Enantiomer.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/stereochemistry-topic/chirality-r-s-system/v/stereoisomer-enantiomer-jay"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::Carbohydrates</div>
A <i>chiral</i> molecule is a type of molecule that&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""lacks"" data-ordinal=""1"">[lacks or has]</span> an&nbsp;internal plane of symmetry&nbsp;and has a&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""non&#x2D;superimposable"" data-ordinal=""1"">[superimposable or non-superimposable]</span>&nbsp;mirror image
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">

<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Glycosphingolipids"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are a subtype of <i>glycolipids</i> and contain a <b>sphingosine</b>, <b>fatty acid</b>, and a&nbsp;<b>sugar unit</b><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::Lipids</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Glycosphingolipids</span> are a subtype of <i>glycolipids</i> and contain a <b>sphingosine</b>, <b>fatty acid</b>, and a&nbsp;<b>sugar unit</b><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Example: <i>Cerebroside</i>, which contains 1 sugar group<br></div><div><br></div><div>Cerebroside Structure:</div><div><img src=""Cerebroside.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://youtu.be/c_RTc7aSFp4"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""ganglioside"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is a molecule composed of a <u>glycosphingolipid</u> with one or more <i>sialic acids</i> linked on the sugar chain
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::Lipids</div>
    A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">ganglioside</span> is a molecule composed of a <u>glycosphingolipid</u> with one or more <i>sialic acids</i> linked on the sugar chain
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>A component of the cell membrane that <b>modulates cell signal transduction</b> events, and appears to concentrate in <b>lipid rafts</b><br></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><br></font></div><div><img src=""Ganglioside.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-nWO63QvayI"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::Lipids MileDown::General_Chemistry::Lipid_Metabolism</div>
    A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">micelle</span> can <i>dissolve</i> <i>a lipid-soluble molecule</i> in its fatty acid core
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>It then <u>washes away with water</u> because of its shell of&nbsp;carboxylate head groups</div><div><br></div><div><b>Formation of micelles is spontaneous</b> because ∆S &gt; O. Overall entropy increases because there are now more unbound water molecules</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Micelle (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MTwUy3c5Etc"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>

    The <i>purines</i> in DNA and RNA have <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">2</span> ring(s)
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Nitrogenous Bases.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/chemical-processes/nucleic-acids-lipids-and-carbohydrates/v/nucleic-acid-structure-1"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Structure</div>
The&nbsp;DNA double helix has a <i>diameter</i> of <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""20"" data-ordinal=""1"">[#]</span> angstroms
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Structure</div>
    The&nbsp;DNA double helix has a <i>diameter</i> of <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">20</span> angstroms
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><i>purine + pyrimidine = uniform width</i><br></div><div>purine + purine = too wide</div><div>pyrimidine + pyrimidine = too narrow</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""DNA Width.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yelx2ZSh7RA"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Structure</div>
The <b>DNA backbone</b> is held together by <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""phosphodiester&amp;nbsp&#x3B;bonds"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... bonds]</span>&nbsp;
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Structure</div>
    The <b>DNA backbone</b> is held together by <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">phosphodiester&nbsp;bonds</span>&nbsp;
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Form between the sugar and the phosphate groups<br></div><div><br></div><div>Nucleotide bases are held together by <u>hydrogen bonds</u></div><div><br></div><div><font color=""#195ab3""><img src=""DNA Structure.png""></font></div><div><font color=""#195ab3""><br></font></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/dna-as-the-genetic-material/dna-replication/v/molecular-structure-of-dna"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Structure</div>
<div><b>Adenine and Thymine</b> are held together by <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""2"" data-ordinal=""1"">[#]</span> hydrogen bonds</div><div><br></div><div><i>Guanine and Cytosine</i> are held together by <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""3"" data-ordinal=""1"">[#]</span> hydrogen bonds</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Structure</div>
    <div><b>Adenine and Thymine</b> are held together by <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">2</span> hydrogen bonds</div><div><br></div><div><i>Guanine and Cytosine</i> are held together by <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">3</span> hydrogen bonds</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Note: RNA has U instead of T<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""DNA Structure.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ILWTGC8KHM"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Chargaff’s&#x20;rules"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... rules]</span> states that, in DNA, the <b>number of purines must equal the&nbsp;number of pyrimidines</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Structure</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Chargaff’s rules</span> states that, in DNA, the <b>number of purines must equal the&nbsp;number of pyrimidines</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>This is due to the base pairing of A-T and G-C</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Nitrogenous Bases.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/dna-as-the-genetic-material/dna-discovery-and-structure/v/the-discovery-of-the-double-helix-structure-of-dna"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Chromosomes</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Telomeres</span> are at the <i>ends of chromosomes</i> and contain high GC-content to <u>prevent&nbsp;unraveling of the DNA</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><b>During replication, telomeres are&nbsp;shortened</b>, but this can be partially reversed by <i>telomerase</i><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Telomere (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/cells/cellular-development/v/telomeres-and-cell-senescence"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Chromosomes</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Centromeres"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are located in the <i>middle of&nbsp;chromosomes</i> and <b>hold&nbsp;sister chromatids&nbsp;together</b> until they are&nbsp;separated during&nbsp;anaphase in mitosis
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Chromosomes</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Centromeres</span> are located in the <i>middle of&nbsp;chromosomes</i> and <b>hold&nbsp;sister chromatids&nbsp;together</b> until they are&nbsp;separated during&nbsp;anaphase in mitosis
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><u>High GC-content</u> to&nbsp;maintain a strong bond&nbsp;between chromatids<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Centromere.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/high-school-biology/hs-reproduction-and-cell-division/hs-chromosome-structure-and-numbers/v/chromosomes-chromatids-chromatin-etc"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><u>Introns are cut out</u><br></div><div><br></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><img src=""Posttranscriptional Modification.jpeg""></font></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><br></font></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-biology/gene-expression-and-regulation/transcription-and-rna-processing/v/post-translational-regulation"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::RNA_Processing</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Exons"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are regions of a gene that <i>code for proteins</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::RNA_Processing</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Exons</span> are regions of a gene that <i>code for proteins</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><i>Exons exit the nucleus</i>&nbsp;and form mRNA&nbsp;<br></div><div><u>Introns stay in the nucleus</u>&nbsp;since they are cut out and not included in mRNA<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Posttranscriptional Modification.jpeg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-expression-central-dogma/transcription-of-dna-into-rna/v/transcription-and-mrna-processing"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::RNA_Processing</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Introns"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are segments of a DNA or RNA molecule which do <u>not code for proteins</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::RNA_Processing</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Introns</span> are segments of a DNA or RNA molecule which do <u>not code for proteins</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><i>Exons exit the nucleus</i>&nbsp;and form mRNA&nbsp;<br></div><div><u>Introns stay in the nucleus</u>&nbsp;since they are cut out and not included in mRNA<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Posttranscriptional Modification.jpeg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-expression-central-dogma/transcription-of-dna-into-rna/v/transcription-and-mrna-processing"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div><br></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::RNA_Processing</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Alternative&#x20;splicing"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is a regulated process during gene expression that <b>results in a&nbsp;single gene coding for multiple proteins</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::RNA_Processing</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Alternative splicing</span> is a regulated process during gene expression that <b>results in a&nbsp;single gene coding for multiple proteins</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>In normal gene expression, <u>introns are cut away</u> and&nbsp;<i>exons remain</i>&nbsp;in the sequence</div><div><br></div><div>In <b>alternative splicing</b>, a certain exon may be cut out, or an intron may&nbsp;stay. This allows for the RNA segment to code for more&nbsp;than one gene<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Alternative Splicing (2).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xZwSmUNRBQQ"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"

    In <u>prokaryotic translation</u>, the <b>30S ribosome</b> subunit attaches to the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Shine-Delgarno sequence</span>&nbsp;and scans for a start codon
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>It lays down <b>N-formylmethionine </b>in the P site of the&nbsp;ribosome</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Translation Initiation.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-biology/gene-expression-and-regulation/translation/v/differences-in-translation-between-prokaryotes-and-eukaryotes"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Translation</div>
A <u>Svedberg</u> is a measure of&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""sedimentation&#x20;time"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>; the tendency of particles to settle out of a fluid
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Translation</div>
    A <u>Svedberg</u> is a measure of&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">sedimentation time</span>; the tendency of particles to settle out of a fluid
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The value depends on both <b>mass and shape</b><br></div><div><i><br></i></div><div>Svedberg units are <i>not additive</i>. For example, prokaryotic ribosomes have a 50S subunit and a 30S subunit, but the total Svedberg unit for the combined ribosome is only 70s</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Ribosome Subunits.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1fUswlOwslw"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Translation</div>
    <u>Prokaryotic</u>&nbsp;ribosomes are <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">70</span> Svedberg units&nbsp;
    <div>&nbsp;</div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Translation</div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Translation</div>
In <b>translation elongation</b>, the&nbsp;new tRNA enters the ribosome at the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""A"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> site
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Translation</div>
    In <b>translation elongation</b>, the&nbsp;new tRNA enters the ribosome at the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">A</span> site
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The growing polypeptide&nbsp;chain is transferred from the P site to the A&nbsp;site to meet the new tRNA</div><div><br></div><div>Before leaving the ribosome, the tRNA stops in the E site. <i>The order of sites for the tRNA is A-P-E</i></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Translation Elongation.jpeg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-expression-central-dogma/translation-polypeptides/v/translation-mrna-to-protein"">Khan Academy Link</a></div>
</div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
In <b>translation</b>, <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""termination"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> will occur when the codon in the A site is a <i>stop codon</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    In <b>translation</b>, <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">termination</span> will occur when the codon in the A site is a <i>stop codon</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Release factor places a <u>water molecule</u> on the&nbsp;polypeptide chain and thus releases the protein<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Translation Termination.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-expression-central-dogma/translation-polypeptides/v/translation-mrna-to-protein"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Translation</div>
<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Post&#x2D;translational&#x20;modifications"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are modifications that occur to a protein <u>after it has been fully formed in translation</u></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Translation</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Post-translational modifications</span> are modifications that occur to a protein <u>after it has been fully formed in translation</u></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>PTMs can happen at any step of the protein lifespan. The most common PTM is <i>phosphorylation</i><br></div><div><br></div><div><i><img src=""Post Translational Modifications (1).png""></i></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/biomolecules/dna/v/protein-modifications"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA::Chromosomes</div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>The prokaryotic chromosome is circular<br><div><br></div><div><b>Eukaryote</b>:</div><div><img src=""Chromosome Eukaryote (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><u>Prokaryote</u>:</div><div><img src=""Chromosome Prokaryote (2).png""></div><div><br></div><div>Note: <i>Plasmids</i> are different from chromosomes and contain DNA that is <i>not essential for survival</i></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i9AbkNGh2u8"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Operons"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are found in <u>prokaryotic DNA</u> and contain groups of genes that are <b>regulated together</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Operons</span> are found in <u>prokaryotic DNA</u> and contain groups of genes that are <b>regulated together</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The advantage is that a group of genes whose products are all needed for a common function can be <b>transcribed together</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>Operons contain&nbsp;<i>activators</i>,&nbsp;<i>inducers, </i>and&nbsp;<i>repressors</i></div><div><br></div><div><i><img src=""Operon.jpg""></i></div><div><i><br></i></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/v/operons-and-gene-regulation-in-bacteria"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
An operon <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""promoter"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the <i>binding site for RNA polymerase</i>, the enzyme that performs <u>transcription</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    An operon <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">operator</span> is a short region of DNA that lies partially within the promoter and&nbsp;<b>interacts with a repressor</b>&nbsp;that controls the transcription of the operon
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Operon Promoter (2).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/a/the-lac-operon"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
An operon <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""repressor"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> <i>turns the operon&nbsp;off</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    An operon <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">repressor</span> <i>turns the operon&nbsp;off</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The repressor&nbsp;<b>binds to the operator</b>&nbsp;and then blocks the movement of RNA polymerase down the DNA strand<br></div><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Operon Inducer (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/a/the-lac-operon"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
An operon <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""activator"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> <u>turns the operon&nbsp;on</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    An operon <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">activator</span> <u>turns the operon&nbsp;on</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Example: <i>lac</i> <i>operon</i> uses catabolite activator protein (CAP)<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Operon Activator (2).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/a/the-lac-operon"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
An operon <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""inducer"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is a small molecule that&nbsp;<b>triggers expression&nbsp;of a gene or operon</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    An operon <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">inducer</span> is a small molecule that&nbsp;<b>triggers expression&nbsp;of a gene or operon</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Example:&nbsp;The <i>lac</i> <i>operon</i> is considered an <b>inducible operon</b> because its default state is to be turned off (repressed), but can be turned on in the presence of the inducer <b>allolactose</b></div><div><font color=""#195ab3""><br></font></div><div><img src=""Operon Inducer (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/a/the-lac-operon"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
An <b>inducible operon</b> under normal conditions is&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""bonded&#x20;to&#x20;a&#x20;repressor"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    An <b>inducible operon</b> under normal conditions is&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">bonded to a repressor</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><b>Inducible operons</b>&nbsp;are&nbsp;turned on when an inducer pulls the repressor&nbsp;from the operator site<br></div><div><br></div><div>Example: <i>lac operon</i> is an inducible operon</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Operon Inducer (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/v/operons-and-gene-regulation-in-bacteria"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
A <i>repressible operon</i> under normal conditions will <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""proceed&#x20;with&#x20;transcription"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    A <i>repressible operon</i> under normal conditions will <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">proceed with transcription</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><i>Repressible operons</i>&nbsp;can be&nbsp;turned off by a corepressor coupling with the&nbsp;repressor and the <u>binding of this complex to the&nbsp;operator site<br></u></div><div><br></div><div>Example: <i>Trp operon</i></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Repressible Operon.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/v/operons-and-gene-regulation-in-bacteria"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>

    <div id='extra'><div><i>This inhibits&nbsp;transcription</i><br></div><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""DNA Methylation (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-biology/gene-expression-and-regulation/regulation-of-gene-expression-and-cell-specialization/v/dna-and-chromatin-regulation"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
The <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Lac&#x20;operon"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;contains genes that <b>code for proteins in charge of transporting lactose</b> into the cytosol and digesting it into glucose
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Lac operon</span>&nbsp;contains genes that <b>code for proteins in charge of transporting lactose</b> into the cytosol and digesting it into glucose
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>This glucose is then used to make <i>energy</i><div><br></div><div>The <i>lac</i>, or <i>lactose</i>,<i> operon</i> is found in <u>E. coli</u> and some other bacteria<div><br></div><div><img src=""Lac Operon.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/a/the-lac-operon"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
The <i>Lac operon</i> is a/an <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""inducible"" data-ordinal=""1"">[repressible or inducible]</span> operon
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    The <i>Lac operon</i> is a/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">inducible</span> operon
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Under normal conditions it is&nbsp;<i>bonded to a repressor</i><br></div><div><div><br></div><div>It is turned on when an inducer pulls the repressor&nbsp;from the operator site</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Operon Inducer (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/v/operons-and-gene-regulation-in-bacteria"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
The genes in the <i>lac operon</i>&nbsp;will be expressed if the following <u>two conditions are met</u>:<div><br></div><div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Lactose&#x20;is&#x20;available"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div><div><br></div><div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Glucose&#x20;is&#x20;low"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div></div></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    The genes in the <i>lac operon</i>&nbsp;will be expressed if the following <u>two conditions are met</u>:<div><br></div><div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Lactose is available</span></div><div><br></div><div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Glucose is low</span></div></div></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>When <b>lactose is available</b>, the inducer (allolactose) binds to the repressor and the repressor detaches from the DNA:<br></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Operon Inducer (1).png""><br></div><div><br></div></div><div>When <u>glucose is low</u>, the activator, <i>catabolite activator protein</i> (CAP), binds to the DNA:</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Operon Activator (2).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/v/operons-and-gene-regulation-in-bacteria"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Allolactose"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> binds to the <i>lac repressor</i> and makes it change shape so the <b>repressor detaches from the DNA</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::DNA_and_RNA</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Allolactose</span> binds to the <i>lac repressor</i> and makes it change shape so the <b>repressor detaches from the DNA</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>When lactose is available, <u>some lactose molecules will be converted to allolactose</u><div><br></div><div><b>This increases the lac operon gene expression</b><br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Operon Inducer (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/gene-regulation/gene-regulation-in-bacteria/v/operons-and-gene-regulation-in-bacteria"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>

    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Sensory ganglia</span> are enlargements along peripheral nerves that <u>transmit signals to the CNS</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Sensory Ganglia.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/human-anatomy-and-physiology/nervous-system-introduction/v/peripheral-somatosensation"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">

Give the <u>visual pathway</u>:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Eye"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""optic&#x20;nerves"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""optic&#x20;chiasm"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""optic&#x20;tracts"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""lateral&#x20;geniculate&#x20;nucleus&#x20;&#x28;LGN&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""visual&#x20;radiations"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""visual&#x20;cortex"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Visual</div>
    Give the <u>visual pathway</u>:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Eye</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">optic nerves</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">optic chiasm</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">optic tracts</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN)</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">visual radiations</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">visual cortex</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Visual Pathway 2.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ETIp8kZPoBw"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

<div>The item missing from the <u>visual pathway</u>:<br></div><div><br></div><div>Eye&nbsp;→&nbsp;optic nerves&nbsp;→&nbsp;optic chiasm&nbsp;→&nbsp;optic tracts&nbsp;→&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""lateral&#x20;geniculate&#x20;nucleus&#x20;&#x28;LGN&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→&nbsp;visual radiations&nbsp;→&nbsp;visual cortex<br></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Visual</div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Auditory</div>
The three main <b>divisions of the ear</b> are <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""outer"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""middle"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, and <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""inner"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Auditory</div>
    The three main <b>divisions of the ear</b> are <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">outer</span>, <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">middle</span>, and <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">inner</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Ear Diagram Enhanced.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/sound-audition-topic/v/auditory-structure-part-1"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Auditory</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Auditory</div>

    <div id='extra'><div>Collects sound and transmits to eardrum</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Outer Ear.jpeg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/sound-audition-topic/v/auditory-structure-part-1"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

Give the <b>auditory pathway</b>:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Cochlea"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""vestibulocochlear&#x20;nerve"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""medial&#x20;geniculate&#x20;nucleus"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""auditory&#x20;cortex"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>

The <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""two&#x2D;point&#x20;threshold"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the <b>minimum distance&nbsp;necessary between two points</b> of&nbsp;stimulation on the skin such that the points will be<i> felt&nbsp;as&nbsp;two distinct stimuli</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception</div>
    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">two-point threshold</span> is the <b>minimum distance&nbsp;necessary between two points</b> of&nbsp;stimulation on the skin such that the points will be<i> felt&nbsp;as&nbsp;two distinct stimuli</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Two Point Sensation.jpg"" style=""color: rgb(25, 90, 179);""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/processing-the-environment/sensory-perception/v/absolute-threshold-of-sensation"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Physiological zero</span> is a temperature that is felt by the skin as&nbsp;<i>neither warm nor cold</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Under ordinary conditions usually falls at about 85° to 90°F</div></div>
</div>"

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Pain</div>
    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">gate control theory</span> of pain&nbsp;asserts that <i>non-painful input closes</i> <i>the nerve ""gates""</i> to painful input, which <b>prevents pain sensation</b> from traveling to the central nervous system
    <div>&nbsp;</div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Gestalt&#x20;principles"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are principles of how our mind <i>groups things</i></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Gestalt principles</span> are principles of how our mind <i>groups things</i></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><b>Proximity<br></b></div><div><div><b>Similarity</b></div><div><b>Continuity</b></div><div><b>Subjective contours</b></div><div><b>Closure</b></div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Gestalt Principles.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/sensory-perception-topic/v/gestalt-principles"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
According to the gestalt principle of <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""proximity"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, objects that are placed <u>close</u> together are <u>perceived as being more related</u> than those spaced farther apart
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
    According to the gestalt principle of <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">proximity</span>, objects that are placed <u>close</u> together are <u>perceived as being more related</u> than those spaced farther apart
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>In the below example, your mind sees&nbsp;set <i>(a)</i> as <i>one group</i> and set <b>(b)</b> as <b>three distinct columns</b> or groups<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Proximity.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/sensory-perception-topic/v/gestalt-principles"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
According to the gestalt principle of <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""similarity"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, we tend to perceive things that <b>physically resemble</b> one another as <b>part of the same object</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
    According to the gestalt principle of <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">similarity</span>, we tend to perceive things that <b>physically resemble</b> one another as <b>part of the same object</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Similarity.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/sensory-perception-topic/v/gestalt-principles"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
According to the gestalt principle of <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""continuity"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, when a shape is not complete, but enough of the shape is shown, <i>our minds will fill in the blanks</i> and construct the whole of the shape
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
    According to the gestalt principle of <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">continuity</span>, when a shape is not complete, but enough of the shape is shown, <i>our minds will fill in the blanks</i> and construct the whole of the shape
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>In the below example, the eye <b>tends to want to follow the straight line</b> from one end of this figure to the other, and the <u>curved line from the top to the bottom</u>, even when the lines change color midway through<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Continuity.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/sensory-perception-topic/v/gestalt-principles"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
According to the gestalt principle of <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""closure"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, we <b>tend to see complete figures</b> even when part of the information is missing
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
    According to the gestalt principle of <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">closure</span>, we <b>tend to see complete figures</b> even when part of the information is missing
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Closure.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/sensory-perception-topic/v/gestalt-principles"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Law&#x20;of&#x20;Pr&#xE4;gnanz"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> states that people will perceive and interpret ambiguous or complex images as the&nbsp;<u>simplest form(s) possible</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Sensation_and_Perception::Gestalt_Principles</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Law of Prägnanz</span> states that people will perceive and interpret ambiguous or complex images as the&nbsp;<u>simplest form(s) possible</u>

    <div id='extra'><div>The&nbsp;Law of Prägnanz <i>governs all the Gestalt Principles</i><br></div><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Law of Pragnanz.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/sensory-perception-topic/v/gestalt-principles"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    Pressure is <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">equal</span> in every direction in a fluid at a given depth
    <div>&nbsp;</div>

<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Absolute&#x20;pressure"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the <i>sum of all pressures</i> at&nbsp;a certain point&nbsp;within a fluid</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Absolute pressure</span> is the <i>sum of all pressures</i> at&nbsp;a certain point&nbsp;within a fluid</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Absolute pressure = (pressure at the surface of the fluid) + (pressure&nbsp;due to the fluid's weight)<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""P Total.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Absolute Pressure.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/fluids/density-and-pressure/a/pressure-article"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    In water, every additional <u>10 meters of depth</u> adds approximately <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">1 atm</span> to P<sub>total</sub>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Water Pressure Every 10 m.png""><br></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
<div><b>Gauge pressure</b> is <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""absolute&#x20;pressure"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... pressure]</span>&nbsp;-&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""atmospheric&#x20;pressure"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... pressure]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    <div><b>Gauge pressure</b> is <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">absolute pressure</span>&nbsp;-&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">atmospheric pressure</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Its the reading that a pressure gauge would show when used to test the pressure of something</div><div><br></div><div>It is zero referenced against atmospheric pressure so if the gauge reads ""0 atm"" that means there is no pressure other than the existing atmospheric pressure&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Guage Pressure.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Absolute Pressure.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/fluids/density-and-pressure/a/pressure-article"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
<div><i>Pascal’s principle</i> states that pressure applied to a fluid will be&nbsp;distributed <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""undiminished"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;throughout the&nbsp;<u>entire volume&nbsp;of the fluid</u></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    <div><i>Pascal’s principle</i> states that pressure applied to a fluid will be&nbsp;distributed <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">undiminished</span>&nbsp;throughout the&nbsp;<u>entire volume&nbsp;of the fluid</u></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>A pressure change at any point in a fluid is transmitted throughout the fluid such that <b>the same change occurs everywhere</b><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Pascal's Law.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Pascal's Law Equation.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/fluids/density-and-pressure/v/fluids-part-1"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
<div><b>Hydraulic machines</b> operate based on the application of&nbsp;Pascal’s principle&nbsp;to&nbsp;generate&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""mechanical&#x20;advantage"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    <div><b>Hydraulic machines</b> operate based on the application of&nbsp;Pascal’s principle&nbsp;to&nbsp;generate&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">mechanical advantage</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Hydraulic Machines.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/fluids/density-and-pressure/v/fluids-part-1"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
<div><u>Archimedes’ principle</u> states that when an object is placed in a fluid, the fluid generates a&nbsp;<b>buoyant force </b>against the object that is equal to the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""weight&#x20;of&#x20;the&#x20;fluid&#x20;displaced&#x20;by&#x20;the&#x20;object"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    <div><u>Archimedes’ principle</u> states that when an object is placed in a fluid, the fluid generates a&nbsp;<b>buoyant force </b>against the object that is equal to the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">weight of the fluid displaced by the object</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>If F<sub>B</sub>&nbsp;&gt; m<sub>object</sub>, then the object floats</div><div>If F<sub>B</sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;m<sub>object</sub>, then the object sinks</div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Archimedes Principle.gif"" style=""color: rgb(25, 90, 179);""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Buoyant Force.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/fluids/buoyant-force-and-archimedes-principle/v/fluids-part-5"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>

<div><u>Cohesion</u>&nbsp;refers to the clinging of&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""like"" data-ordinal=""1"">[like or unlike]</span> molecules</div><div><br></div><div><br><i>Adhesion</i>&nbsp;refers to the clinging of&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""unlike"" data-ordinal=""1"">[like or unlike]</span> molecules<br></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    <div><u>Cohesion</u>&nbsp;refers to the clinging of&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">like</span> molecules</div><div><br></div><div><br><i>Adhesion</i>&nbsp;refers to the clinging of&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">unlike</span> molecules<br></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Capillary action occurs when the adhesive forces to the wall are <b>stronger</b> than the cohesive forces between the liquid molecules<br></div><div><br></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><img src=""Cohesion Adhesion.jpeg""></font></div>
<div><br></div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/water-acids-and-bases/cohesion-and-adhesion/a/cohesion-and-adhesion-in-water"">Khan Academy Link</a></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
<b>Capillary action</b> occurs when the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""adhesive&#x20;forces"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... forces]</span> to the wall are stronger than the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""cohesive&#x20;forces"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... forces]</span> between the liquid molecules
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    <b>Capillary action</b> occurs when the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">adhesive forces</span> to the wall are stronger than the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">cohesive forces</span> between the liquid molecules
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The wall of the container just above the water surface attracts water molecules upwards through the force of adhesion<br></div><div><br></div><div>In capillary action, <i>adhesion</i> &gt; <u>cohesion</u></div><div><br></div><img src=""Capillary Action.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/water-acids-and-bases/cohesion-and-adhesion/v/capillary-action-and-why-we-see-a-meniscus"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Flow rate = volume / time</div><div><br></div><div>Or, flow rate = (velocity) x (cross sectional area)</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Flow Rate 2.png""></div><div><br></div><img src=""Flow Rate.png""><div><br></div><div>A = cross sectional area</div><div>v = velocity</div><div><br></div>

<div><img src=""Venturi Tube (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div>The <b>Venturi tube</b> demonstrates that as cross-sectional area <u>decreases</u> from point 1 to point 2, the linear speed must <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""increase"" data-ordinal=""1"">[increase or decrease]</span><br></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    <div><img src=""Venturi Tube (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div>The <b>Venturi tube</b> demonstrates that as cross-sectional area <u>decreases</u> from point 1 to point 2, the linear speed must <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">increase</span><br></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The average height of the horizontal tube remains constant, so pgh remains constant at points 1 and 2<br></div><div><br></div><div>As the dynamic pressure increases, the absolute pressure must decrease at point 2, causing the column of fluid sticking up from the Venturi tube be to be lower at point 2</div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lyk_HloXz-E"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
The <u>Coulomb's law proportionality constant</u> (in air) is k = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""9&#x2E;0&#x20;x&#x20;10&lt;sup&gt;9&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;&amp;nbsp&#x3B;N&#x20;•&#x20;m&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;&amp;nbsp&#x3B;&#x2F;&#x20;C&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
    The <u>Coulomb's law proportionality constant</u> (in air) is k = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">9.0 x 10<sup>9</sup>&nbsp;N • m<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;/ C<sup>2</sup></span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The units on k are such that when placed into the Coulomb's Law equation the units on charge (Coulombs) and the units on distance (meters) will be canceled, <i>leaving a Newton as the unit of force</i><br></div><div><br></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><img src=""Coulomb's Law.png""></font></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><br></font></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-electric-charge-electric-force-and-voltage/coulombs-law-and-electric-force-ap/v/coulombs-law"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
    <i>Field lines </i>show the activity of a&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">positive</span> test charge
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><u>Used to represent the electric field vectors for a charge</u></div><div><br></div><div>Move away from a positive charge and move&nbsp;toward a negative charge (north to south)<br></div><div><br></div><div><b>The field is&nbsp;stronger where the field lines are closer together</b></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Electric Field Lines.jpeg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/electric-charge-electric-force-and-voltage/electric-field/v/electrostatics-part-2"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
<div>A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""equipotential"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> line is a line on which the&nbsp;<b>potential at every point is the same</b></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
    <div>A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">equipotential</span> line is a line on which the&nbsp;<b>potential at every point is the same</b></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Equipotential lines are always<i> perpendicular </i>to electrical&nbsp;field lines<br></div><div><br></div><div>No work is done when a charge moves along an equipotential line<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Equipotential Lines (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1XI4D4SgHTw"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""electric&#x20;dipole"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is a <u>separation of positive and negative charges</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
    A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">electric dipole</span> is a <u>separation of positive and negative charges</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The simplest example of this is a pair of electric charges of equal magnitude but opposite sign, separated by some (usually small) distance<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Electric Dipole.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RZxyjv8YF3k"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
    <div>A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">dipole moment</span> is a measure of the&nbsp;<i>separation</i>&nbsp;of positive and negative electrical charges within a system</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>It is the product of charge (q) and separation distance (d)<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Dipole Moment Equation.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Dipole Moment Diagram.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/chemistry/chemical-bonds/copy-of-dot-structures/v/dipole-moment"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Electrical potential energy</span> is the <b>amount of work</b> required to bring a&nbsp;test&nbsp;charge&nbsp;from infinitely far away to a given position in the vicinity of a source&nbsp;charge
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Electrical Potential Energy.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Electric Potential Energy Equation.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/electric-charge-electric-force-and-voltage/electric-potential-voltage/v/electric-potential-energy"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

<b>Electric potential energy</b> <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""increases"" data-ordinal=""1"">[increases or decreases]</span> when like charges move closer together or when opposite charges move apart
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>

    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Electrical Potential Energy.png""><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/electric-charge-electric-force-and-voltage/electric-potential-voltage/v/electric-potential-energy"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Electrical potential</span> is the&nbsp;<i>potential energy</i>&nbsp;of a unit charge in any electric field
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Different points in the space of an electric field surrounding a source charge&nbsp;will have different electrical potential values<br></div><div><br></div><div>Note:&nbsp;<i>Electric potential is</i> <i>not the same</i> <i>as electric potential difference</i>. Electric potential difference, also called <b>voltage</b>, is the difference of electric potentials of two different points</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Electrical Potential Energy.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/electric-charge-electric-force-and-voltage/electric-potential-voltage/v/electric-potential-energy"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Electrostatics</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Voltage</span> is the <b>potential&nbsp;difference</b> in charge&nbsp;between two points in an electrical field
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The greater the voltage, the greater the flow of electrical current<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Voltage.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Volt Breakdown.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/electric-charge-electric-force-and-voltage/electric-potential-voltage/v/voltage"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Circuits</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Current"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the <b>flow of electric charge</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Circuits</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Current</span> is the <b>flow of electric charge</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>By convention, current is&nbsp;defined as the movement of <i>positive charge</i><br></div><div><br></div><div>In&nbsp;reality, <u>only electrons actually move</u>&nbsp;in a circuit, but the notation goes opposite of these negative charges</div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Electric Current.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Electric Current 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div>Note: The above diagram shows the direction of electric charge in regards to how it is notated. Remember, in reality, the <u>only things that move are electrons</u> and they move up to a higher voltage</div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/electrical-engineering/introduction-to-ee/intro-to-ee/v/ee-current"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Circuits</div>
<div>The <i>junction rule</i> states that the sum of the currents flowing into a junction is <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""equal&#x20;to"" data-ordinal=""1"">[greater than, less than, or equal to]</span> the sum of the currents flowing out of that junction</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Circuits</div>
    <div>The <i>junction rule</i> states that the sum of the currents flowing into a junction is <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">equal to</span> the sum of the currents flowing out of that junction</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Junction Rule Equation.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Junction Rule.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-circuits-topic/kirchhoffs-junction-rule/a/kirchhoffs-junction-rule-ap1"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Circuits</div>
The <u>loop rule</u> states that the&nbsp;sum&nbsp;of all the&nbsp;electric potential differences&nbsp;(voltages) around a loop is&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""zero"" data-ordinal=""1"">[#]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Circuits</div>
    The <u>loop rule</u> states that the&nbsp;sum&nbsp;of all the&nbsp;electric potential differences&nbsp;(voltages) around a loop is&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">zero</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>The sum of voltage sources is&nbsp;always equal to the sum of voltage drops</div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Loop Rule.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Loop Law Equation.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-circuits-topic/kirchhoffs-loop-rule-ap/v/ee-kirchhoffs-voltage-law"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

The <i>Reynolds number</i> is used to check whether the flow is&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""laminar"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""turbulent"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Fluids</div>
    The <i>Reynolds number</i> is used to check whether the flow is&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">laminar</span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">turbulent</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><u>Laminar</u> flow occurs at <u>low</u> Reynolds numbers<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Reynolds Number 3.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div>ρ&nbsp;= density of fluid</div><div>V = velocity</div><div>L = diameter of pipe</div><div>μ&nbsp;= dynamic viscosity of the fluid</div><div><br></div><div><i>Reynolds number is dimensionless</i></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/fluids/fluid-dynamics/v/turbulence-at-high-velocities-and-reynolds-number"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
    When a membrane is <u>depolarized</u>, the membrane <b>potential</b> becomes more <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">positive</span> compared to its resting potential
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div><img src=""Action Potential 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/neuron-membrane-potentials-topic/v/neuron-action-potential-mechanism"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Membrane&#x20;potential"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is an&nbsp;<b>electrical potential difference</b>&nbsp;between the inside and outside of a cell
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Membrane potential</span> is an&nbsp;<b>electrical potential difference</b>&nbsp;between the inside and outside of a cell
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Imagine taking two electrodes and placing one on the <u>inside</u> and the other on the <u>outside</u> of the plasma membrane. If you did this, you would measure an <b>electrical potential difference</b>, or <i>voltage</i>, between the electrodes</div><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Membrane Potential (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/human-biology/neuron-nervous-system/a/the-membrane-potential"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>

"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">

    <i>Depolarization</i> occurs when <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Na<sup>+</sup></span>&nbsp;ions flow in
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>This <i>increases</i> the charge inside the cell and results in depolarization of the cell membrane<div><br><div><img src=""Na Channel.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Action Potential (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/neuron-membrane-potentials-topic/v/neuron-action-potential-mechanism"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
    Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;ions enter the cell through <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;channels</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The Na<sup>+&nbsp;</sup><b>concentration gradient&nbsp;</b>is what drives the movement of Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;ions</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Na Channel.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Action Potential (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/neuron-membrane-potentials-topic/v/neuron-action-potential-mechanism"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Hyperpolarization"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is when the&nbsp;membrane potential&nbsp;dips <u>below</u> <u>the</u> <u>resting potential</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Hyperpolarization</span> is when the&nbsp;membrane potential&nbsp;dips <u>below</u> <u>the</u> <u>resting potential</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>While hyperpolarized, the neuron is in a <b>refractory period</b> during which&nbsp;another stimulus given to the neuron (no matter how strong) will <i>not</i>&nbsp;lead to a second action potential<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Action Potential (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/neuron-membrane-potentials-topic/v/neuron-action-potential-mechanism"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
Hyperpolarization occurs because <b>K<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;channels</b> are&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""slow&#x20;to&#x20;close"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
    Hyperpolarization occurs because <b>K<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;channels</b> are&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">slow to close</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>K<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;continues to <u>exit</u> the cell even though resting potential was already reached<br></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Action Potential (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/nervous-system-and-sensory-infor/neuron-membrane-potentials-topic/v/neuron-action-potential-mechanism"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
The <i>Na</i><sup style=""""><i>+</i></sup>/&nbsp;<u>K<sup style="""">+</sup></u><i>&nbsp;</i>Pump&nbsp;moves <i>Na<sup>+</sup></i> and <u>K<sup style="""">+</sup></u> in the following amounts and directions<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""3"" data-ordinal=""1"">[amount]</span> <i>Na</i><sup><i>+</i>&nbsp;</sup><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""out&#x20;of"" data-ordinal=""1"">[direction]</span> the cell</div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""2"" data-ordinal=""1"">[amount]</span> <u>K</u><sup><u>+</u>&nbsp;</sup><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""into"" data-ordinal=""1"">[direction]</span> the cell</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential</div>
    The <i>Na</i><sup style=""""><i>+</i></sup>/&nbsp;<u>K<sup style="""">+</sup></u><i>&nbsp;</i>Pump&nbsp;moves <i>Na<sup>+</sup></i> and <u>K<sup style="""">+</sup></u> in the following amounts and directions<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">3</span> <i>Na</i><sup><i>+</i>&nbsp;</sup><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">out of</span> the cell</div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">2</span> <u>K</u><sup><u>+</u>&nbsp;</sup><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">into</span> the cell</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Mnemonic:</div><div>3-2-1 NOKIA</div><div><i>3 Na<sup>+</sup> Out</i></div><div><b>2 K<sup>+</sup> In</b></div><div>1 ATP used</div><div><br></div>Pumps ions <i>against</i> their concentration gradient<div><br></div><div>Helps to restore the <u>concentration gradient</u> and restore the&nbsp;<u>resting potential</u> across the cell membrane<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Na K Pump.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Action Potential (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/human-biology/neuron-nervous-system/v/sodium-potassium-pump"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Synapses</div>
An <i>excitatory postsynaptic potential</i> (EPSP) <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""depolarizes"" data-ordinal=""1"">[depolarizes or hyperpolarizes]</span> the cell
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Synapses</div>
    An <i>excitatory postsynaptic potential</i> (EPSP) <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">depolarizes</span> the cell
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>It makes the inside of the cell <i>more positive</i>, bringing the membrane potential <b>closer to its threshold</b> for firing an action potential<div><br></div><div><img src=""EPSP IPSP.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/human-biology/neuron-nervous-system/a/the-synapse"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Action_Potential MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Synapses</div>
    An <u>inhibitory post-synaptic</u> <u>potential</u> (IPSP)&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">hyperpolarizes</span> the cell
    <div>&nbsp;</div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Synapses</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Synapses</div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Neurotransmitters MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Synapses</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Neurotransmitters"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;are stored in <u>synaptic vesicles</u> and are released when <i>Ca<sup>2+</sup></i>&nbsp;enters the axon terminal in response to an action potential
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Neurotransmitters MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Synapses</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Neurotransmitters</span>&nbsp;are stored in <u>synaptic vesicles</u> and are released when <i>Ca<sup>2+</sup></i>&nbsp;enters the axon terminal in response to an action potential
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Synapse.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/human-biology/neuron-nervous-system/v/neuronal-synapses-chemical"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Membrane-spanning <i>ion channel</i> proteins that open <i>directly</i> in response to <i>ligand</i> binding<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Ionotropic and Metabotropic (1).jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/organ-systems/biosignaling/v/ligand-gated-ion-channels"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
