<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Neurotransmitters</div>
<u>Metabotropic</u> receptors operate via <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""indirect"" data-ordinal=""1"">[direct or indirect]</span> neurotransmitter action
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Nervous_System::Neurotransmitters</div>
    <u>Metabotropic</u> receptors operate via <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">indirect</span> neurotransmitter action
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>Neurotransmitter binding triggers a <u>signaling pathway</u>, which may <u>indirectly</u> open or close channels<div><br></div><div>Metabotropic receptors are <b>not themselves</b> ion channels<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Ionotropic and Metabotropic (1).jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/human-anatomy-and-physiology/nervous-system-introduction/v/types-of-neurotransmitter-receptors"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Endocrine</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""G&#x2D;Protein&#x20;Coupled&#x20;Receptor&#x20;&#x28;GPCR&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is a membrane receptor that <u>transfers a signal from outside the cell to the inside of the cell</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Endocrine</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">G-Protein Coupled Receptor (GPCR)</span> is a membrane receptor that <u>transfers a signal from outside the cell to the inside of the cell</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>About 50% of all modern drugs target GPCRs<br></div><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""GPCR.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-biology/cell-communication-and-cell-cycle/signal-transduction/v/g-protein-coupled-receptors"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Endocrine</div>

The <b>G-Protein</b>&nbsp;is classified as a <i>heterotrimeric</i> <i>protein</i> because <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""it&#x20;is&#x20;made&#x20;up&#x20;of&#x20;3&#x20;subunits&#x3A;&amp;nbsp&#x3B;&lt;b&gt;α&lt;&#x2F;b&gt;&#x2C;&amp;nbsp&#x3B;&lt;b&gt;β&lt;&#x2F;b&gt;&#x2C;&amp;nbsp&#x3B;&lt;b&gt;γ&lt;&#x2F;b&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Endocrine</div>
    The <b>G-Protein</b>&nbsp;is classified as a <i>heterotrimeric</i> <i>protein</i> because <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">it is made up of 3 subunits:&nbsp;<b>α</b>,&nbsp;<b>β</b>,&nbsp;<b>γ</b></span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>The G-Protein is made up of&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><img src=""Heterotrimeric G Protein.jpeg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-biology/cell-communication-and-cell-cycle/signal-transduction/v/g-protein-coupled-receptors"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Endocrine</div>
In the term <u>G-protein</u>, the ""G"" refers to <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""the&#x20;fact&#x20;that&#x20;they&#x20;bind&#x20;GTP&#x20;and&#x20;GDP&amp;nbsp&#x3B;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Endocrine</div>
    In the term <u>G-protein</u>, the ""G"" refers to <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">the fact that they bind GTP and GDP&nbsp;</span><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>GTP = guanosine triphosphate</div><div>GPD = guanosine diphosphate<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""G Protein and GTP.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-biology/cell-communication-and-cell-cycle/signal-transduction/v/g-protein-coupled-receptors"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Endocrine</div>
Give the steps in the <b>GPCR</b> sequence:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&lt;div&gt;1&#x20;&#x2D;&#x20;Ligand&#x20;binds&#x20;to&#x20;GPCR&lt;&#x2F;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;2&#x20;&#x2D;&#x20;GPCR&#x20;undergoes&#x20;conformational&#x20;change&lt;&#x2F;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;3&#x20;&#x2D;&#x20;Alpha&#x20;subunit&#x20;exchanges&#x20;GDP&#x20;for&#x20;GTP&lt;&#x2F;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;4&#x20;&#x2D;&#x20;Alpha&#x20;subunit&#x20;dissociates&#x20;and&#x20;regulates&#x20;target&#x20;proteins&lt;&#x2F;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;5&#x20;&#x2D;&#x20;Target&#x20;protein&#x20;relays&#x20;signal&#x20;as&#x20;2nd&#x20;messenger&#x20;and&#x20;triggers&#x20;cascade&#x20;response&lt;&#x2F;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;6&#x20;&#x2D;&#x20;GTP&#x20;is&#x20;hydrolyzed&#x20;to&#x20;GDP&#x2C;&#x20;everything&#x20;returns&#x20;to&#x20;its&#x20;original&#x20;place&#x2C;&#x20;ready&#x20;to&#x20;repeat&#x20;the&#x20;sequence&lt;&#x2F;div&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Endocrine</div>
    Give the steps in the <b>GPCR</b> sequence:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1""><div>1 - Ligand binds to GPCR</div><div>2 - GPCR undergoes conformational change</div><div>3 - Alpha subunit exchanges GDP for GTP</div><div>4 - Alpha subunit dissociates and regulates target proteins</div><div>5 - Target protein relays signal as 2nd messenger and triggers cascade response</div><div>6 - GTP is hydrolyzed to GDP, everything returns to its original place, ready to repeat the sequence</div></span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""GPCR.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-biology/cell-communication-and-cell-cycle/signal-transduction/v/g-protein-coupled-receptors"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"

    <b>Antidiuretic hormone</b>&nbsp;(ADH) promotes&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">increased</span> water retention and&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">deceased</span> plasma osmolarity
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><i>Increases&nbsp;blood pressure</i><br></div><div><br></div><u>Produced in the hypothalamus</u><div><br></div><div><b>Released from the posterior pituitary</b></div><div><br></div><div><div style=""color: rgb(178, 100, 26); ""><font color=""#195ab3""><img src=""Hypothalamus Hormones.jpg""></font></div><div style=""color: rgb(178, 100, 26); ""><font color=""#195ab3""><br></font></div><div><font color=""#195ab3""><span style=""color: rgb(25, 90, 179)""><img src=""ADH (1).png""></span></font></div><div style=""color: rgb(178, 100, 26); ""><font color=""#195ab3""><br></font></div><div style=""color: rgb(178, 100, 26); ""><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/circulatory-system/blood-pressure-control/v/aldosterone-and-adh"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>T<sub>4</sub>&nbsp;= Thyroxine</div><div>T<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;= Triiodothyronine</div></div><div><br></div><div>Also helps regulate calcium homeostasis</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Thyroid Gland.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/advanced-endocrine-system/endocrine-system-introduction/v/endocrine-gland-hormone-review"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Endocrine</div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Learning</div>
<u>Schedules of reinforcement</u> can be based on&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""intervals"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> or <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""the&#x20;ratio&amp;nbsp&#x3B;of&#x20;behavior&#x20;&#x2F;&#x20;reward"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Learning</div>
    <u>Schedules of reinforcement</u> can be based on&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">intervals</span> or <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">the ratio&nbsp;of behavior / reward</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Schedules of reinforcement.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/behavior/learning-slug/v/operant-conditioning-schedules-of-reinforcement"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

<u>Piaget’s</u> four stages of cognitive development:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Sensorimotor&#x3A;&#x20;0&amp;nbsp&#x3B;→&#x20;2"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Preoperational&#x3A;&#x20;2&#x20;→&#x20;7"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div><div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Concrete&#x20;Operational&#x3A;&#x20;7&#x20;→&#x20;11"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div><div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Formal&#x20;Operational&#x3A;&#x20;12&#x20;and&#x20;older"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div></div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Development</div>
    <u>Piaget’s</u> four stages of cognitive development:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Sensorimotor: 0&nbsp;→ 2</span><div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Preoperational: 2 → 7</span></div><div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Concrete Operational: 7 → 11</span></div><div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Formal Operational: 12 and older</span></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Alkanes"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are hydrocarbons in which all carbon–carbon bonds are&nbsp;<b>single</b> bonds
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Alkanes</span> are hydrocarbons in which all carbon–carbon bonds are&nbsp;<b>single</b> bonds
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Alkanes.png"" style=""vertical-align: sub; color: rgb(25, 90, 179);""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/bond-line-structures-alkanes-cycloalkanes/naming-alkanes/v/naming-simple-alkanes"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
<i>Alkanes</i> are named according to the&nbsp;number of <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""carbons"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;present followed by the suffix <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""–&lt;i&gt;ane&lt;&#x2F;i&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
    <i>Alkanes</i> are named according to the&nbsp;number of <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">carbons</span>&nbsp;present followed by the suffix <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">–<i>ane</i></span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Straight Chain Alkanes.png"" style=""vertical-align: sub;""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/bond-line-structures-alkanes-cycloalkanes/naming-alkanes/v/naming-simple-alkanes"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
<b>Alkenes</b> have a <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""double"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> bond and use the suffix <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&#x2D;ene"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
    <b>Alkenes</b> have a <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">double</span> bond and use the suffix <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">-ene</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><i><img src=""Alkene.png""></i><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/alkenes-alkynes/naming-alkenes/v/naming-alkenes-examples"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
<u>Alkynes</u> have a&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""triple"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> bond and use the suffix <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""–yne"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
    <u>Alkynes</u> have a&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">triple</span> bond and use the suffix <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">–yne</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><i><img src=""Alkyne.png""></i><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/alkenes-alkynes/naming-preparation-alkynes/v/alkyne-nomenclature"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
<i>Alcohols</i> have a/an&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""–OH"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> group and use the suffix <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""–ol"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;or prefix <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""hydroxy&#x2D;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
    <i>Alcohols</i> have a/an&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">–OH</span> group and use the suffix <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">–ol</span>&nbsp;or prefix <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">hydroxy-</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Alcohols have <i>higher priority</i> than double or triple bonds</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Alcohol (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/alcohols-ethers-epoxides-sulfides/alcohol-nomenclature-properties/v/alcohols"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
<u>Ketones</u> have carbonyl group on a&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""non&#x2D;terminal"" data-ordinal=""1"">[terminal or non-terminal]</span>&nbsp;carbon
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
    <u>Ketones</u> have carbonyl group on a&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">non-terminal</span>&nbsp;carbon
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Aldehyde vs Ketone.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/aldehydes-ketones/nomenclature-aldehyde-ketone/v/nomenclature-of-aldehydes-and-ketones"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
<i style="""">Alcohols</i> are classified as <i>1º</i>,<i> 2º</i>,<i> </i>and<i> 3º </i>alcohols&nbsp;according to the number of carbons attached to the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""carbon&#x20;bearing&#x20;the&#x20;hydroxyl&#x20;group"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>
    <i style="""">Alcohols</i> are classified as <i>1º</i>,<i> 2º</i>,<i> </i>and<i> 3º </i>alcohols&nbsp;according to the number of carbons attached to the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">carbon bearing the hydroxyl group</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>In other words, whether the hydroxyl is bound to a primary, secondary, or tertiary carbon<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Alcohol (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/alcohols-ethers-epoxides-sulfides/alcohol-nomenclature-properties/v/alcohol-nomenclature"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Nomenclature</div>

Have different physical and chemical properties</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Structural Isomers (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Isomer Chart (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.dropbox.com/s/s5k5bv5swqbhjij/Screenshot 2019-04-15 17.37.54.png?dl=0"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
    The two categories of <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">configurational isomers</span> are <b>enantiomers</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>diastereomers</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>Can only change from one form to another by <i>breaking and reforming</i> bonds<div><i><br></i></div><div><img src=""Isomer Chart (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/stereochemistry-topic/diastereomers-meso-compounds/v/stereoisomers-enantiomers-diastereomers-constitutional-isomers-and-meso-compounds"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Enantiomers"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> are stereoisomers that are&nbsp;<u>non-superimposable</u>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<u>are mirror images</u>&nbsp;of each other
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Enantiomers</span> are stereoisomers that are&nbsp;<u>non-superimposable</u>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<u>are mirror images</u>&nbsp;of each other
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Same&nbsp;chemical and physical properties, <i>except for&nbsp;rotation of plane polarized light</i></div><div><i><br></i></div><div><img src=""Enantiomers.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Isomer Chart (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/stereochemistry-topic/diastereomers-meso-compounds/v/stereoisomers-enantiomers-diastereomers-constitutional-isomers-and-meso-compounds"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Relative&#x20;configuration"" data-ordinal=""1"">[.. configuration]</span> gives the stereochemistry of a compound relative to the D- and L- forms of&nbsp;<i>glyceraldehyde</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Relative configuration</span> gives the stereochemistry of a compound relative to the D- and L- forms of&nbsp;<i>glyceraldehyde</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>In a Fischer projection, look at&nbsp;the highest numbered chiral carbon</div><div><br></div><div>If -OH is on the <i>right</i> then it is a <i>D-sugar</i>.<i>&nbsp;</i>If&nbsp;-OH is on <b>left</b> then it is an <b>L-sugar</b></div><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""D and L Configuration (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://chem.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/Organic_Chemistry/Book:_Basic_Principles_of_Organic_Chemistry_(Roberts_and_Caserio)/19:_More_on_Stereochemistry/19.05:_Absolute_And_Relative_Configuration"">Chem Libre Link</a><br></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
The <b>stereochemistry</b> of the α-carbon in all eukaryotic <i>amino acids</i>&nbsp;(except glycine) is <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""L"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
    The <b>stereochemistry</b> of the α-carbon in all eukaryotic <i>amino acids</i>&nbsp;(except glycine) is <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">L</span>&nbsp;
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""All Amino Acids Are L Config.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HG4bqgGR3DI"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
<div>Cahn-Ingold-Prelog priority rules are rules for <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""naming&#x20;stereoisomers"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
    <div>Cahn-Ingold-Prelog priority rules are rules for <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">naming stereoisomers</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Priority is given by looking at <u>atoms connected to&nbsp;the chiral carbon</u> or double-bonded carbons. Whichever has the <b>highest atomic #</b> <b>gets</b> <b>highest&nbsp;priority</b></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Cahn Ingold.png""><br></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/stereochemistry-topic/optical-activity/v/cahn-ingold-prelog-system-for-naming-enantiomers"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
In the E-Z naming system for alkenes:<div><br></div><div><div>(<i>Z</i>) has the highest priority on <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""the&#x20;same"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> side(s)</div><div><br></div><div>(<u>E</u>) has the highest priority on <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""opposite"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> side(s)</div></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Isomers</div>
    In the E-Z naming system for alkenes:<div><br></div><div><div>(<i>Z</i>) has the highest priority on <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">the same</span> side(s)</div><div><br></div><div>(<u>E</u>) has the highest priority on <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">opposite</span> side(s)</div></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""E-Z.png""><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""E-Z 2.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/alkenes-alkynes/naming-alkenes-jay/v/e-z-system-new"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Bonding::Quantum_Numbers</div>
Quantum number <i>n</i> is the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""principal"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;quantum number and gives the electron <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&lt;i&gt;energy&#x20;level&lt;&#x2F;i&gt;&amp;nbsp&#x3B;or&amp;nbsp&#x3B;&lt;i&gt;shell&#x20;number&lt;&#x2F;i&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Bonding::Quantum_Numbers</div>
    Quantum number <i>n</i> is the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">principal</span>&nbsp;quantum number and gives the electron <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1""><i>energy level</i>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<i>shell number</i></span><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div><div>1, 2, 3, ...</div><div><br></div><div>Except for d- and f-orbitals,&nbsp;the shell # matches the row of&nbsp;the periodic table</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Principal Quantum Number.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Quantum Numbers.png""></div><div><br></div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/quantum-physics/quantum-numbers-and-orbitals/v/quantum-numbers"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Bonding::Quantum_Numbers</div>
Quantum number <b>l </b>is the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""azimuthal"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;quantum number and gives the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&lt;i&gt;3D&#x20;shape&lt;&#x2F;i&gt;&amp;nbsp&#x3B;&#x28;subshell&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;of an orbital<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Bonding::Quantum_Numbers</div>
    Quantum number <b>l </b>is the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">azimuthal</span>&nbsp;quantum number and gives the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1""><i>3D shape</i>&nbsp;(subshell)</span>&nbsp;of an orbital<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>0, 1, 2, …, n-1</div><div><br></div><div>0 = s orbital</div><div><div>1 = p orbital</div><div>2 = d orbital</div><div>3 = f orbital</div><div>4 = g orbital</div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Azimuthal Quantum Number.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Quantum Numbers.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/quantum-physics/quantum-numbers-and-orbitals/v/quantum-numbers"">Khan Academy Link</a></div><div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Bonding::Quantum_Numbers</div>
Quantum number <u>m<sub>l</sub></u>&nbsp;is the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""magnetic"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;quantum number and gives the orbital <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""sub&#x2D;type"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Bonding::Quantum_Numbers</div>
    Quantum number <u>m<sub>l</sub></u>&nbsp;is the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">magnetic</span>&nbsp;quantum number and gives the orbital <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">sub-type</span><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Integers&nbsp;-l&nbsp;to&nbsp;+l</div><div><br></div><div>The orientation of the electron's orbital with respect to the three axes in space, x, y, and z.</div><div><div><br></div></div><div><img src=""Magnetic Quantum Number.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Quantum Numbers.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/quantum-physics/quantum-numbers-and-orbitals/v/quantum-numbers"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>+1/2 or -1/2</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Spin Quantum Number.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Quantum Numbers.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/quantum-physics/quantum-numbers-and-orbitals/v/quantum-numbers"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Bonding</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Molecular"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;orbitals are obtained by <i>combining</i> the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""atomic"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;orbitals from the individual atoms that make up the molecule
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Bonding</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Molecular</span>&nbsp;orbitals are obtained by <i>combining</i> the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">atomic</span>&nbsp;orbitals from the individual atoms that make up the molecule
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Molecular orbital theory is able to explain why some bonds between atoms are observed to be <i>in between</i> a single and a double bond. Valence-bond theory, the more traditional theory, cannot explain these ""hybridized"" bonds</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Molecular Orbitals.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nTujP4jCbsg"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Bonding</div>
    <u>Bonding orbitals</u> are created by overlap of&nbsp;atomic orbitals of the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">same</span> sign

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Brønsted-Lowry</span> acid is a <u>proton</u> donor
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Bronsted Lowery Acid and Base.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/chemical-processes/acid-base-equilibria/v/acid-base-definitions-1"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
An&nbsp;<i>S<sub style="""">N</sub>1</i><span style=""color: rgb(225, 39, 39)""> </span>reaction has <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""two"" data-ordinal=""1"">[#]</span> step(s)
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    An&nbsp;<i>S<sub style="""">N</sub>1</i><span style=""color: rgb(225, 39, 39)""> </span>reaction has <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">two</span> step(s)
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Step 1: &nbsp;The <u>LG leaves</u>, forming a <u>carbocation</u><br></div><div><div><br></div><div>Step 2: The <i>nucleophile attacks</i> the planar carbocation from either&nbsp;side, leading to a <i>racemic mixture </i>of products</div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Sn1.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Sn1 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/substitution-elimination-reactions/sn1-sn2-tutorial/v/sn1-mechanism-carbocation-rearrangement"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
An&nbsp;S<sub>N</sub>2 reaction has <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""one"" data-ordinal=""1"">[#]</span> step(s)
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    An&nbsp;S<sub>N</sub>2 reaction has <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">one</span> step(s)
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>The&nbsp;nucleophile attacks at the <b>same time</b> as the LG leaves</div></div><div><br></div><div><div>The&nbsp;nucleophile must perform a <i>backside attack</i>, which leads to&nbsp;<i>inversion of stereochemistry</i></div></div><div><i><br></i></div><div><img src=""Sn2 (1).png""></div><div><i><br></i></div><div><i><img src=""Sn2 2.png""></i></div><div><i><br></i></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/substitution-elimination-reactions/sn1-sn2-tutorial/v/sn2-mechanism-and-stereochemistry"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""S&lt;sub&gt;N&lt;&#x2F;sub&gt;1"" data-ordinal=""1"">[S<sub>N</sub>1 or S<sub>N</sub>2]</span>&nbsp;products are a <i>racemic</i> mixture
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">S<sub>N</sub>1</span>&nbsp;products are a <i>racemic</i> mixture
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>In the 2nd step,&nbsp;the <b>nucleophile attacks</b> the planar carbocation from <b>either&nbsp;side</b>, leading to a racemic mixture of products</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Sn1 Racemic Mixture.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/substitution-elimination-reactions/sn1-sn2-tutorial/v/sn1-mechanism-carbocation-rearrangement"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""S&lt;sub&gt;N&lt;&#x2F;sub&gt;2"" data-ordinal=""1"">[S<sub>N</sub>1 or S<sub>N</sub>2]</span>&nbsp;reactions lead to <u>inversion</u> of stereochemistry
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">S<sub>N</sub>2</span>&nbsp;reactions lead to <u>inversion</u> of stereochemistry
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>The&nbsp;nucleophile must perform a <u>backside attack</u>, which leads to</div><div><u>inversion</u> of stereochemistry</div></div><div><br></div><div><font color=""#195ab3""><div><img src=""Sn2 (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/substitution-elimination-reactions/sn1-sn2-tutorial/v/sn2-mechanism-and-stereochemistry"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></font></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
The rate law for an&nbsp;<i>S<sub style="""">N</sub>1</i>&nbsp;reaction is <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""S&lt;sub&gt;N&lt;&#x2F;sub&gt;1&amp;nbsp&#x3B;Rate&amp;nbsp&#x3B;&#x3D;&#x20;k&#x5B;substrate&#x5D;&lt;sup&gt;1&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    The rate law for an&nbsp;<i>S<sub style="""">N</sub>1</i>&nbsp;reaction is <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">S<sub>N</sub>1&nbsp;Rate&nbsp;= k[substrate]<sup>1</sup></span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>A <i>first-order</i> reaction</div><div><br></div><img src=""Unimolecular.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yrvV85H737o"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
The rate law for an&nbsp;<b>S<sub style="""">N</sub>2</b>&nbsp;reaction is <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""S&lt;sub&gt;N&lt;&#x2F;sub&gt;2&amp;nbsp&#x3B;Rate&amp;nbsp&#x3B;&#x3D;&#x20;k&#x5B;substrate&#x5D;&lt;sup&gt;1&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;&#x5B;nucleophile&#x5D;&lt;sup&gt;1&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    The rate law for an&nbsp;<b>S<sub style="""">N</sub>2</b>&nbsp;reaction is <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">S<sub>N</sub>2&nbsp;Rate&nbsp;= k[substrate]<sup>1</sup>[nucleophile]<sup>1</sup></span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>A <b>second-order</b> reaction<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Bimolecular.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yrvV85H737o"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
<img src=""Primary Substrate.png""><div><br></div><div>A <u>primary</u> substrate will go <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""S&lt;sub&gt;N&lt;&#x2F;sub&gt;2"" data-ordinal=""1"">[S<sub>N</sub>1&nbsp;or&nbsp;S<sub>N</sub>2]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    <img src=""Primary Substrate.png""><div><br></div><div>A <u>primary</u> substrate will go <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">S<sub>N</sub>2</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>1 step<br></div><div><br></div><div>If you were to do an&nbsp;S<sub>N</sub>1&nbsp;reaction on a primary substrate, you'd get a <i>primary carbocation</i>, which is very <i>unstable</i></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Sn1 Sn2 Chart 2 (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yrvV85H737o"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
<img src=""Tertiary Substrate.png""><div><br></div><div>A <b>tertiary</b> substrate with a protic&nbsp;(or aprotic) solvent will go <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""S&lt;sub&gt;N&lt;&#x2F;sub&gt;1"" data-ordinal=""1"">[S<sub>N</sub>1&nbsp;or&nbsp;S<sub>N</sub>2]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    <img src=""Tertiary Substrate.png""><div><br></div><div>A <b>tertiary</b> substrate with a protic&nbsp;(or aprotic) solvent will go <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">S<sub>N</sub>1</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>2 steps<div><br></div><div>There is too much <i>steric hinderance</i> for the nucleophile to attack the carbon while the leaving group is still there. The LG must leave first</div><div><br></div><div>The products will be a mixture of&nbsp;S<sub>N</sub>1&nbsp;and E1</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Sn1 Sn2 Chart 2 (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yrvV85H737o"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    <img src=""Secondary with Protic.jpg""><div><br></div><div>This reaction will go <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">S<sub>N1</sub></span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>The substrate is <i>secondary</i>&nbsp;and CH<sub>3</sub>OH is a <i>protic</i> solvent<div><br></div><div><img src=""Secondary Protic and Aprotic Complete.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Sn1 Sn2 Chart 2 (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MrzUZSETgFc"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
<b>S<sub style="""">N</sub>2</b>&nbsp;reactions prefer <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""methyl&#x20;and&#x20;primary"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> substrates
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    <b>S<sub style="""">N</sub>2</b>&nbsp;reactions prefer <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">methyl and primary</span> substrates
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>It is easy for the nucleophile to attack the carbon because the <b>carbon is accessible</b> (less steric hindrance)</div><div><br></div><div>The reaction can proceed in <b>1 step</b><br></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Sn1 Sn2 Chart 2 (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yrvV85H737o"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
<div><img src=""Methyl Substrate.png""></div><div><br></div>A <u>methyl</u> substrate <i>cannot</i> undergo an <b>elimination</b> reaction because elimination reactions create <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""double&#x20;bonds&#x20;between&#x20;two&#x20;carbons&#x2C;&#x20;C&#x3D;C"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    <div><img src=""Methyl Substrate.png""></div><div><br></div>A <u>methyl</u> substrate <i>cannot</i> undergo an <b>elimination</b> reaction because elimination reactions create <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">double bonds between two carbons, C=C</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>There is only one carbon in a methyl so no double bond can be created<div><br></div><div><img src=""Sn1 Sn2 Chart 2 (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yrvV85H737o"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    <b>Strong bases</b> favor <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">E2</span> reactions

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    Polar <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">protic</span> solvents are capable of&nbsp;<u>hydrogen bonding</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Polar Protic: <u>Acetic Acid</u>, <u>H<sub style="""">2</sub>O</u>,&nbsp;<u>ROH</u>, <u>NH<sub style="""">3</sub></u></div><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Polar Protic Solvents.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/substitution-elimination-reactions/sn1-sn2-tutorial/v/sn1-vs-sn2-solvent-effects"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
Polar <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""aprotic"" data-ordinal=""1"">[protic or aprotic]</span> solvents <i>do not</i> participate in&nbsp;<u>hydrogen bonding</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>
    Polar <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">aprotic</span> solvents <i>do not</i> participate in&nbsp;<u>hydrogen bonding</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Polar Aprotic:&nbsp;<i>DMF</i>, <i>DMSO</i>,&nbsp;<i>Acetone</i>, <i>Ethyl Acetate</i></div><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Polar Aprotic Solvents.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/substitution-elimination-reactions/sn1-sn2-tutorial/v/sn1-vs-sn2-solvent-effects"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Reactions</div>

<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Alcohols"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> use suffix <i>–ol</i>&nbsp;or prefix&nbsp;<i>hydroxy-</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Alcohols</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Alcohols</span> use suffix <i>–ol</i>&nbsp;or prefix&nbsp;<i>hydroxy-</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Contains an&nbsp;<u>–OH</u> group</div><div><br></div><div>Alcohols have&nbsp;<b>higher</b> priority&nbsp;than double or triple bonds</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Alcohols (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/alcohols-ethers-epoxides-sulfides/alcohol-nomenclature-properties/v/alcohols"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Alcohols</div>
1º, 2º, and 3º alcohols are named according to the <b>number of carbons</b> attached to&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""the&#x20;carbon&#x20;bearing&#x20;the&#x20;hydroxyl&#x20;group"" data-ordinal=""1"">[which carbon]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Alcohols</div>
    1º, 2º, and 3º alcohols are named according to the <b>number of carbons</b> attached to&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">the carbon bearing the hydroxyl group</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>In other words, whether the hydroxyl is bound to a primary, secondary, or tertiary <b>carbon</b><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Alcohols (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/alcohols-ethers-epoxides-sulfides/alcohol-nomenclature-properties/v/alcohol-nomenclature"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Alcohols</div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Oxidation of an alcohol removes the H and adds a second bond to the O to make a <i>carbonyl</i><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Alcohol Oxidize and Reduce Chart (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/alcohols-ethers-epoxides-sulfides/reactions-alcohols-tutorial/v/oxidation-of-alcohols-i-mechanism-and-oxidation-states"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

<u>Peptide Bonds</u> are formed when the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""N&#x2D;terminus"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;of an amino acid <b>nucleophilically</b> attacks the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""C&#x2D;terminus"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;of another amino acid
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Amino_Acids</div>
    <u>Peptide Bonds</u> are formed when the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">N-terminus</span>&nbsp;of an amino acid <b>nucleophilically</b> attacks the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">C-terminus</span>&nbsp;of another amino acid
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Condensation reaction<br></div><div><br></div><div>Can be <i>cleaved</i>&nbsp;<i>hydrolytically </i>using a&nbsp;strong acid or base</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Peptide Bonds 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/macromolecules/proteins-and-amino-acids/v/peptide-bond-formation"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Amino_Acids</div>
In a <u>peptide bond</u>, rotation of the C-N bond is <i>restricted</i> due to <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""resonance"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Amino_Acids</div>
    In a <u>peptide bond</u>, rotation of the C-N bond is <i>restricted</i> due to <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">resonance</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Resonance causes the C-N bond to take on a <i>partial double bond</i> character</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Peptide Bond Partial Double Bond.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/biomolecules/amino-acids-and-proteins1/a/chemistry-of-amino-acids-and-protein-structure"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Phosphorus_Containing_Compounds</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Phosphoric acid</span> is sometimes referred to as a&nbsp;<i>phosphate group</i>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<u>inorganic phosphate</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Denoted as <b>Pi</b></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><br></font></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><img src=""Phosphoric Acid (1).png""></font></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><br></font></div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=id1yK29TTcc"">YouTube Link</a></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations MileDown::OChem::Phosphorus_Containing_Compounds</div>
<i>Phosphoric acid</i> is an <b>excellent buffer</b> because it contains three hydrogens, each with <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""a&#x20;unique&#x20;pK&lt;sub&gt;a&lt;&#x2F;sub&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations MileDown::OChem::Phosphorus_Containing_Compounds</div>
    <i>Phosphoric acid</i> is an <b>excellent buffer</b> because it contains three hydrogens, each with <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">a unique pK<sub>a</sub></span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The&nbsp;wide variety in pK<sub>a</sub> values allows phosphoric acid to act&nbsp;as a buffer over a<u> large range of pH values</u></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Phosphoric Acid pKa.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=id1yK29TTcc"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Phosphorus_Containing_Compounds</div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>

    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Pleural Membrane 2.png"">&nbsp;</div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/respiratory-system-diseases/pleural-effusion-2/v/what-is-pleural-effusion"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
During <i>inspiration</i>, lung volume <b>expands</b>&nbsp;as a result of the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""contraction"" data-ordinal=""1"">[contraction or relaxation]</span> of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles, this expands&nbsp;the thoracic cavity
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
    During <i>inspiration</i>, lung volume <b>expands</b>&nbsp;as a result of the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">contraction</span> of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles, this expands&nbsp;the thoracic cavity
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Due to this increase in volume, the <u>pressure is decreased</u><br></div><div><br></div><div>The pressure gradient between the atmosphere and the thoracic cavity allows air to rush into the lungs; inhalation occurs</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Inspiration Pressure Gradient.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/human-anatomy-and-physiology/lung-introduction/v/inhaling-and-exhaling"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
During <u>exhalation</u>, the diaphragm muscles <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""relax"" data-ordinal=""1"">[contract or relax]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
    During <u>exhalation</u>, the diaphragm muscles <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">relax</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>There is&nbsp;an <i>elastic recoil</i> of the lung tissue which causes a decrease in volume<br></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Inspiration Pressure Gradient.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/human-anatomy-and-physiology/lung-introduction/v/inhaling-and-exhaling"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
<i>Inhalation</i> is considered a/an <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""active&#x20;process"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... process]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
    <i>Inhalation</i> is considered a/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">active process</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Because the diaphragm must <i>contract</i> for inhalation</div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Diaphragm Contraction.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/human-anatomy-and-physiology/lung-introduction/v/inhaling-and-exhaling"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>

    <div id='extra'><div><i>It cannot measure total volume<br></i></div><div><i><br></i></div><div><img src=""Spirometer.jpeg""></div></div>

<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Residual&#x20;volume"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the amount of air that remains in a person's lungs&nbsp;after <u>fully exhaling</u></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Residual volume</span> is the amount of air that remains in a person's lungs&nbsp;after <u>fully exhaling</u></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Some air must stay in the lungs to <b>keep the alveoli from collapsing</b><br></div><div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Lung Volume Chart.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=chMedJwp4wo"">YouTube Link</a></div></div></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Vital&#x20;capacity"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the difference between <u>minimum</u> and <i>maximum</i>&nbsp;volume of air in the lungs
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Vital capacity</span> is the difference between <u>minimum</u> and <i>maximum</i>&nbsp;volume of air in the lungs
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>This is the maximum amount of air a person can <b>expel</b> from the lungs after a maximum inhalation<br></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Lung Volume Chart.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=chMedJwp4wo"">YouTube Link</a></div></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Cilia</span>&nbsp;function together using their&nbsp;<u>wave-like motion</u>&nbsp;to&nbsp;<b>move mucus&nbsp;up and away from the lungs</b> and back into the throat
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>This is the <i>mucociliary escalator&nbsp;</i></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Mucociliary Escalator.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HMB6flEaZwI"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System::Bicarbonate_Buffer MileDown::General_Chemistry::Equilibrium</div>
The <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""bicarbonate&#x20;buffer"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is by far the most important <i>buffer for&nbsp;maintaining acid-base balance</i>&nbsp;in the blood
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System::Bicarbonate_Buffer MileDown::General_Chemistry::Equilibrium</div>
    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">bicarbonate buffer</span> is by far the most important <i>buffer for&nbsp;maintaining acid-base balance</i>&nbsp;in the blood
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Bicarbonate Buffer.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Bicarbonate Buffer.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ArmELNEfXs0"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System::Bicarbonate_Buffer MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations MileDown::General_Chemistry::Equilibrium</div>
If the <u>blood pH is too&nbsp;low</u>, respiration will <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""increase"" data-ordinal=""1"">[increase or decrease]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System::Bicarbonate_Buffer MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations MileDown::General_Chemistry::Equilibrium</div>
    If the <u>blood pH is too&nbsp;low</u>, respiration will <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">increase</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Respiration goes up&nbsp;to <u>blow off CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;</u></div><div><br></div><div>Based on <b>Le Châtelier’s Principle</b>, the bicarbonate buffer will <u>shift left </u>to remove H<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;which will raise the pH back to normal levels</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Bicarbonate Buffer.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ArmELNEfXs0"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System::Bicarbonate_Buffer MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations MileDown::General_Chemistry::Equilibrium</div>
If the <i>blood pH is</i> <i>too</i>&nbsp;<i style="""">high</i>, respiration will <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""decrease"" data-ordinal=""1"">[increase or decrease]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System::Bicarbonate_Buffer MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations MileDown::General_Chemistry::Equilibrium</div>
    If the <i>blood pH is</i> <i>too</i>&nbsp;<i style="""">high</i>, respiration will <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">decrease</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>Respiration goes<font color=""#195ab3"">&nbsp;</font>down, <i>trapping CO<sub style="""">2</sub></i><div><br></div><div>Based on <b>Le Châtelier’s Principle</b>, the bicarbonate buffer will <i>shift right</i> to add more H<sup>+</sup> which will lower the pH<br><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Bicarbonate Buffer.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ArmELNEfXs0"">YouTube Link</a></div></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
The <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""medulla&#x20;oblongata"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the <u>primary respiratory control center</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Respiratory_System</div>
    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">medulla oblongata</span> is the <u>primary respiratory control center</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>It is part of the <u>brainstem</u><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Medulla Oblongata.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/behavior/biological-basis-of-behavior-ner/v/brainstem"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
Give the <i>blood pathway</i>&nbsp;(including valves) starting in the <b>right atrium</b>:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""right&#x20;atrium"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""tricuspid&#x20;valve"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> → <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""right&#x20;ventricle"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""pulmonary&#x20;valve"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""pulmonary&#x20;artery"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""lungs"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""pulmonary&#x20;veins"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""left&#x20;atrium"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""mitral&#x20;valve"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""left&#x20;ventricle"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""aortic&#x20;valve"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""aorta"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""arteries"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""arterioles"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""capillaries"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""venules"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""veins"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""venae&#x20;cavae"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""right&#x20;atrium"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
    Give the <i>blood pathway</i>&nbsp;(including valves) starting in the <b>right atrium</b>:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">right atrium</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">tricuspid valve</span> → <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">right ventricle</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">pulmonary valve</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">pulmonary artery</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">lungs</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">pulmonary veins</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">left atrium</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">mitral valve</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">left ventricle</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">aortic valve</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">aorta</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">arteries</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">arterioles</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">capillaries</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">venules</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">veins</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">venae cavae</span>&nbsp;→ <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">right atrium</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Blood Pathway.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Blood Flow Through Heart.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/circulatory-system/circulatory-system-introduction/v/flow-through-the-heart"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Systole</span> is the part of the cardiac cycle during which some chambers of the heart muscle <b>contract</b> after refilling with blood
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div><i>AV valves are closed</i><br></div><div><br></div><div><u>Semilunar valves are open</u></div><div><font color=""#e12727""><br></font></div><div>Blood pumps from the chambers into the arteries</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Systole and Diastole.png""></div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Lub Dub Graph.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/circulatory-system/blood-pressure-ddp/v/what-is-blood-pressure-1"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
    <b>ADH</b> promotes&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">increased</span> <u>water retention</u> and&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">decreased</span> <i>plasma osmolarity</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Antidiuretic hormone (Vasopressin)</div><div><br></div><div><i>Increases&nbsp;blood pressure</i></div><div><br></div><div><font color=""#195ab3""><img src=""ADH (2).png""></font></div><div><font color=""#195ab3""><br></font></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/circulatory-system/blood-pressure-control/v/aldosterone-and-adh"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
If your&nbsp;<b>blood osmolarity</b> is<i>&nbsp;</i><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""higher"" data-ordinal=""1"">[higher or lower]</span>&nbsp;than normal, your body reacts to replace this water loss by&nbsp;<i>releasing&nbsp;ADH</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
    If your&nbsp;<b>blood osmolarity</b> is<i>&nbsp;</i><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">higher</span>&nbsp;than normal, your body reacts to replace this water loss by&nbsp;<i>releasing&nbsp;ADH</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>ADH leads to <u>increased water resorption</u> by your kidneys</div><div><br></div><div>Osmolarity goes down and blood pressure goes up<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""High Blood Osmolarity.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/circulatory-system/blood-pressure-control/v/aldosterone-and-adh"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
    <div>The <b>binding of oxygen<sub>&nbsp;</sub>to&nbsp;hemoglobin</b> can be characterized as <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">cooperative</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>When one O<sub style="""">2</sub>&nbsp;molecule binds to one of the four heme groups in a hemoglobin, <i>it becomes more&nbsp;likely</i> that the remaining sites will bind to O<sub style="""">2</sub></div><div><sub style=""""><br></sub></div><div><sub><img src=""Hemoglobin and Myoglobin Dissociation Curves.png""></sub></div><div><sub><br></sub></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/advanced-hematologic-system/hematologic-system-introduction/v/hemoglobin-moves-o2-and-co2"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
<div><b>CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sup>+</sup> </b>will&nbsp;trigger the heme group to <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""release"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> its <u>O<sub>2</sub></u></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
    <div><b>CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sup>+</sup> </b>will&nbsp;trigger the heme group to <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">release</span> its <u>O<sub>2</sub></u></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;and H<sup>+ </sup><i>allosterically inhibit </i>hemoglobin</div><div><br></div><div><div>This means <u>O<sub>2</sub> is released near lots of CO<sub>2</sub></u> <u>or in acidic sites</u>,&nbsp;which is&nbsp;where respiration is happening and <b>O<sub>2</sub> is needed</b></div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Factors Affecting Oxygen Binding.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/advanced-hematologic-system/hematologic-system-introduction/v/hemoglobin"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
A <b>low pH </b>means a <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""low"" data-ordinal=""1"">[high or low]</span> <u>heme affinity for O<sub>2</sub></u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
    A <b>low pH </b>means a <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">low</span> <u>heme affinity for O<sub>2</sub></u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><i>H<sup>+</sup> is an inhibitor of heme</i>, so it causes the heme to release its O<sub>2</sub></div><div><br></div><div>This is called the <u>Bohr Shift</u>. The oxygen saturation curve will <u>shift right</u> in response to a low pH (high H<sup>+</sup> concentration)</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Bohr Shift.jpeg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/advanced-hematologic-system/hematologic-system-introduction/v/bohr-effect-vs-haldane-effect"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>

The <u>myoglobin oxygen saturation</u> curve is <i>hyperbolic</i> because <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""it&amp;nbsp&#x3B;only&#x20;has&#x20;one&#x20;heme&#x20;group&#x20;and&#x20;cannot&#x20;exhibit&amp;nbsp&#x3B;cooperative&amp;nbsp&#x3B;binding"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
    The <u>myoglobin oxygen saturation</u> curve is <i>hyperbolic</i> because <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">it&nbsp;only has one heme group and cannot exhibit&nbsp;cooperative&nbsp;binding</span>

2,3-BPG has <i>no affect</i> on <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""myoglobin"" data-ordinal=""1"">[hemoglobin or myoglobin]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Cardiovascular_System</div>
    2,3-BPG has <i>no affect</i> on <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">myoglobin</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>BPG works by binding in the space <b>between</b> <b>the subunits in hemoglobin</b>. "<div id=""kard"">

<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Period&#x20;&#x28;T&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the&nbsp;number of seconds&nbsp;it takes to <i>complete a&nbsp;cycle</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Period (T)</span> is the&nbsp;number of seconds&nbsp;it takes to <i>complete a&nbsp;cycle</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>It is the <u>inverse of frequency</u><br></div><div><br></div><div>Period is a measure of time</div><div><br></div><div>Wavelength is a measure of length</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Period (3).png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Period (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-mechanical-waves-and-sound/wave-characteristics-ap/v/amplitude-period-frequency-and-wavelength-of-periodic-waves"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Displacement&#x20;&#x28;x&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> refers to&nbsp;how far a point is<b> from the equilibrium&nbsp;position</b>, expressed as a vector quantity
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Displacement (x)</span> refers to&nbsp;how far a point is<b> from the equilibrium&nbsp;position</b>, expressed as a vector quantity
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The term can apply to any measure of <i>length</i> including&nbsp;<i>amplitude</i> and <i>wavelength</i><br></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Wave.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-mechanical-waves-and-sound/wave-characteristics-ap/v/amplitude-period-frequency-and-wavelength-of-periodic-waves"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<i>Angular Frequency (ω)</i> also known as&nbsp;<b>radial</b>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<b>circular</b>&nbsp;frequency, measures&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""angular&#x20;displacement"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;per <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""unit&#x20;time"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <i>Angular Frequency (ω)</i> also known as&nbsp;<b>radial</b>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<b>circular</b>&nbsp;frequency, measures&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">angular displacement</span>&nbsp;per <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">unit time</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Angular Frequency 2.gif""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Angular Frequency.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-centripetal-force-and-gravitation/introduction-to-uniform-circular-motion-ap/v/connecting-period-and-frequency-to-angular-velocity"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Transverse&#x20;waves"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... waves]</span> are oscillations where particles are displaced&nbsp;<i>perpendicular</i>&nbsp;to the wave direction
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Transverse waves</span> are oscillations where particles are displaced&nbsp;<i>perpendicular</i>&nbsp;to the wave direction
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><b>Light is a transverse wave</b> because its components vibrate perpendicular to the direction of propagation<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Transverse Wave (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-mechanical-waves-and-sound/introduction-to-transverse-and-longitudinal-waves-ap/a/transverse-and-longitudinal-waves-ap1"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Longitudinal&#x20;waves"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... waves]</span> are oscillations where particles are displaced&nbsp;<u>parallel</u>&nbsp;to the wave direction
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Longitudinal waves</span> are oscillations where particles are displaced&nbsp;<u>parallel</u>&nbsp;to the wave direction
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><b>Sound waves are longitudinal waves</b> because particles of the medium through which the sound is transported vibrate parallel to the direction that the sound wave moves<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Longitudinal Waves.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-mechanical-waves-and-sound/introduction-to-transverse-and-longitudinal-waves-ap/a/transverse-and-longitudinal-waves-ap1"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    Light&nbsp;is a&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">transverse wave</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Light&nbsp;is a&nbsp;transverse wave&nbsp;because its components vibrate <i>perpendicular</i> to the direction of propagation<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Transverse Wave (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-mechanical-waves-and-sound/introduction-to-transverse-and-longitudinal-waves-ap/a/transverse-and-longitudinal-waves-ap1"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Interference"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> describes the ways in which&nbsp;waves interact&nbsp;in&nbsp;space to&nbsp;form a <b>resultant wave</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Interference</span> describes the ways in which&nbsp;waves interact&nbsp;in&nbsp;space to&nbsp;form a <b>resultant wave</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Interference.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/physical-processes/light-and-electromagnetic-radiation-questions/v/wave-interference"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Constructive&#x20;interference"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... interference]</span> occurs when waves are&nbsp;<u>exactly in phase</u>&nbsp;with each&nbsp;other</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Constructive interference</span> occurs when waves are&nbsp;<u>exactly in phase</u>&nbsp;with each&nbsp;other</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The <b>amplitude</b> of the resultant wave is&nbsp;equal to the <b>sum</b> of the amplitudes of the two&nbsp;interfering waves<br></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Interference.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/physical-processes/light-and-electromagnetic-radiation-questions/v/wave-interference"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Destructive&#x20;interference"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... interference]</span> occurs when waves are&nbsp;<i>exactly out of phase</i>&nbsp;with&nbsp;each other</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Destructive interference</span> occurs when waves are&nbsp;<i>exactly out of phase</i>&nbsp;with&nbsp;each other</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The <u>amplitude</u> of the resultant wave&nbsp;is equal to the <u>difference</u> in amplitude between&nbsp;the two interfering waves<br></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Interference.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/physical-processes/light-and-electromagnetic-radiation-questions/v/wave-interference"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Partially&#x20;constructive&#x20;&#x2F;&#x20;destructive&#x20;interference"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... interference]</span> occurs when two waves are&nbsp;<u>not quite perfectly in&nbsp;or out&nbsp;of phase with each other</u></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Partially constructive / destructive interference</span> occurs when two waves are&nbsp;<u>not quite perfectly in&nbsp;or out&nbsp;of phase with each other</u></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The <b>displacement</b>&nbsp;of the resultant wave is equal to the <b>sum</b> of the&nbsp;displacements of the two interfering waves<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Partial Interference.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/physical-processes/light-and-electromagnetic-radiation-questions/v/wave-interference"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Traveling&#x20;waves"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... waves]</span> <b>have</b> <b>continuously shifting points of maximum&nbsp;and minimum displacement</b> so that the&nbsp;peak of the wave ""travels"" forward
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Traveling waves</span> <b>have</b> <b>continuously shifting points of maximum&nbsp;and minimum displacement</b> so that the&nbsp;peak of the wave ""travels"" forward
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Example: <u>Ocean waves</u> travel over a long distance. As opposed to standing waves that would appear to stay in one spot<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Traveling vs Standing Wave.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eu1PC4botbM"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Standing&#x20;waves"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... waves]</span> oscillate in time but the <i>peak amplitude&nbsp;profile&nbsp;does not move in space</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Standing waves</span> oscillate in time but the <i>peak amplitude&nbsp;profile&nbsp;does not move in space</i>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Produced by the <u>constructive</u> and <b>destructive&nbsp;interference</b> of two waves of the same frequency&nbsp;traveling in opposite directions in the same space<br></div><div><br></div><div><div><img src=""Traveling vs Standing Wave.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eu1PC4botbM"">YouTube Link</a></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>
<b>Nodes</b> are points where there is&nbsp;no <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""oscillation"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Found in&nbsp;<i>standing waves</i>&nbsp;when there are&nbsp;two waves&nbsp;with&nbsp;<i>destructive interference</i><br></div><div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Node (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-physics-1/ap-mechanical-waves-and-sound/standing-waves-ap/v/standing-waves-on-strings"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Waves</div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Sound</div>
