<img src=""Punnet Squares Blank.png""><div><br></div><div>A <u>dihybrid cross</u>, shown above, will result in the following phenotypic ratios:<br><div><br></div><div>Expressed AB: <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""9&#x2F;16"" data-ordinal=""1"">[.../16]</span></div><div>Expressed Ab: <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""3&#x2F;16"" data-ordinal=""1"">[.../16]</span></div><div>Expressed aB: <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""3&#x2F;16"" data-ordinal=""1"">[.../16]</span></div><div>Expressed ab: <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""1&#x2F;16"" data-ordinal=""1"">[.../16]</span></div></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Genetics</div>
    <img src=""Punnet Squares Blank.png""><div><br></div><div>A <u>dihybrid cross</u>, shown above, will result in the following phenotypic ratios:<br><div><br></div><div>Expressed AB: <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">9/16</span></div><div>Expressed Ab: <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">3/16</span></div><div>Expressed aB: <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">3/16</span></div><div>Expressed ab: <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">1/16</span></div></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><i>9:3:3:1</i></div><div><br></div><div><u>Dihybrid cross</u>&nbsp;means a cross involving two traits and each parent organism is <b>heterozygous</b> for both of the traits.</div><div><br></div><img src=""Punnet Squares.png""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y1PCwxUDTl8"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Genetics</div>
When two&nbsp;genes&nbsp;are <b>close together on the same chromosome</b>, they <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""do&#x20;not&#x20;assort&#x20;independently"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> and are said to be&nbsp;<b>linked</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Genetics</div>
    When two&nbsp;genes&nbsp;are <b>close together on the same chromosome</b>, they <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">do not assort independently</span> and are said to be&nbsp;<b>linked</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Linked Genes.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/classical-genetics/chromosomal-basis-of-genetics/a/linkage-mapping"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Genetics</div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Biology::Genetics</div>
The <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""farther&#x20;apart"" data-ordinal=""1"">[closer together or farther apart]</span> two alleles are on the same chromosome, the more likely they are to <b>assort independently</b>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Genetics</div>
    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">farther apart</span> two alleles are on the same chromosome, the more likely they are to <b>assort independently</b>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Linked Genes.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/classical-genetics/chromosomal-basis-of-genetics/a/linkage-mapping"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Genetics</div>
    Give the <i>Hardy-Weinberg</i>&nbsp;equation:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">P<sup>2</sup> + 2Pq + q<sup>2</sup> = 1</span><br></div>

<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Disruptive&#x20;selection"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... selection]</span>&nbsp;will cause organisms with intermediate traits to reproduce less often, and will allow those organisms with extreme traits (multiple traits) to reproduce more often. <b>This drives a population apart</b><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biology::Evolution</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Disruptive selection</span>&nbsp;will cause organisms with intermediate traits to reproduce less often, and will allow those organisms with extreme traits (multiple traits) to reproduce more often. <b>This drives a population apart</b><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>

<img src=""Unit Circle 30 Deg.png""><div><br></div><div>cos(30º) = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&#x5C;&#x28;&#x5C;frac&#x7B;&#x5C;sqrt&#x20;3&#x7D;&#x7B;2&#x7D;&#x5C;&#x29;&#x20;≈&#x20;0&#x2E;9"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br><div><div><br></div><div>sin(30º) = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&#x5C;&#x28;&#x5C;frac&#x7B;1&#x7D;&#x7B;2&#x7D;&#x5C;&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div></div></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Unit_Circle</div>
    <img src=""Unit Circle 30 Deg.png""><div><br></div><div>cos(30º) = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">\(\frac{\sqrt 3}{2}\) ≈ 0.9</span><br><div><div><br></div><div>sin(30º) = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">\(\frac{1}{2}\)</span></div></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Unit_Circle</div>
<img src=""Unit Circle 45 Deg.png""><div><br></div><div>cos(45º) = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&#x5C;&#x28;&#x5C;frac&#x7B;&#x5C;sqrt&#x20;2&#x7D;&#x7B;2&#x7D;&#x5C;&#x29;&#x20;&#x3D;&#x20;0&#x2E;7"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br><div><div><br></div><div>sin(45º) = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&#x5C;&#x28;&#x5C;frac&#x7B;&#x5C;sqrt&#x20;2&#x7D;&#x7B;2&#x7D;&#x5C;&#x29;&#x20;&#x3D;&#x20;0&#x2E;7"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div></div></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Unit_Circle</div>
    <img src=""Unit Circle 45 Deg.png""><div><br></div><div>cos(45º) = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">\(\frac{\sqrt 2}{2}\) = 0.7</span><br><div><div><br></div><div>sin(45º) = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">\(\frac{\sqrt 2}{2}\) = 0.7</span></div></div></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Unit Circle Quadrant 1.png""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ao4EJzNWmK8"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>

<div>Give tangent as a function of cosine and sine:</div><div><br></div>tan(θ) =&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&#x5C;&#x28;&#x5C;frac&#x7B;y&#x7D;&#x7B;x&#x7D;&#x5C;&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> =&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&#x5C;&#x28;&#x5C;frac&#x7B;sin&#x28;θ&#x29;&#x7D;&#x7B;cos&#x28;θ&#x29;&#x7D;&#x5C;&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Unit_Circle</div>
    <div>Give tangent as a function of cosine and sine:</div><div><br></div>tan(θ) =&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">\(\frac{y}{x}\)</span> =&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">\(\frac{sin(θ)}{cos(θ)}\)</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/math/geometry/hs-geo-trig/hs-geo-trig-ratios-intro/v/basic-trigonometry"">Khan Academy Link</a></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Logarithms</div>
<u>x = log<sub>b</sub>(y)</u>&nbsp;can also be written <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""y&#x20;&#x3D;&#x20;b&lt;sup&gt;x&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Logarithms</div>
    <u>x = log<sub>b</sub>(y)</u>&nbsp;can also be written <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">y = b<sup>x</sup></span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Log Rule 1.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAW7WRFBKdw"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Logarithms</div>
<u>x = ln(y)</u>&nbsp;can also be written <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""y&#x20;&#x3D;&#x20;e&lt;span&#x20;style&#x3D;&quot;font&#x2D;size&#x3A;&#x20;16&#x2E;6667px&#x3B;&quot;&gt;&lt;sup&gt;x&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;&lt;&#x2F;span&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Logarithms</div>
    <u>x = ln(y)</u>&nbsp;can also be written <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">y = e<span style=""font-size: 16.6667px;""><sup>x</sup></span></span><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Ln Rule.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAW7WRFBKdw"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

<div>log(A x B) = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""log&#x28;A&#x29;&#x20;&#x2B;&#x20;log&#x28;B&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Logarithms</div>
\(log(\frac{A}{B})\) = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""log&#x28;A&#x29;&#x20;−&#x20;log&#x28;B&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Logarithms</div>
    \(log(\frac{A}{B})\) = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">log(A) − log(B)</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Log Laws.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAW7WRFBKdw"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Mathematics::Logarithms</div>
    log(A<sup>B</sup>) = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">B•log(A)</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions</div>
In a 1 molar solution, <i>normality</i> can be thought of as the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""number&#x20;of&#x20;protons&#x20;a&#x20;molecule&#x20;of&#x20;acid&#x20;can&#x20;release&#x20;in&#x20;solution"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions</div>
    In a 1 molar solution, <i>normality</i> can be thought of as the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">number of protons a molecule of acid can release in solution</span><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>For example, each molecule of <u>H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub></u>&nbsp;can release two protons in solution, so its normality is 2<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Normality 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Normality (1).jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/lab-values/v/what-is-an-equivalent"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

<b>K<sub>sp</sub></b>​ is the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""equilibrium&amp;nbsp&#x3B;constant"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;for a reaction that consists of a solid dissolving in a solution&nbsp;<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
    <b>K<sub>sp</sub></b>​ is the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">equilibrium&nbsp;constant</span>&nbsp;for a reaction that consists of a solid dissolving in a solution&nbsp;<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The equilibrium constant for a regular chemical reaction is abbreviated K<sub>eq</sub></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Qsp vs Ksp.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xly2k0UDTOo"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
Give the solubility product constant for the following chemical equation:<div><br></div><div><i>BaSO<sub style="""">4(s)</sub>&nbsp;⇌ Ba<sup style="""">2+</sup><sub style="""">(aq)</sub>&nbsp;+ SO<sub style="""">4</sub><sup style="""">2-</sup><sub style="""">(aq)</sub></i></div><div><br></div><div>K<sub>sp</sub>&nbsp;= <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&#x5B;Ba&lt;sup&gt;2&#x2B;&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;&#x5D;&#x5B;SO&lt;sub&gt;4&lt;&#x2F;sub&gt;&lt;sup&gt;2&#x2D;&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;&#x5D;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
    Give the solubility product constant for the following chemical equation:<div><br></div><div><i>BaSO<sub style="""">4(s)</sub>&nbsp;⇌ Ba<sup style="""">2+</sup><sub style="""">(aq)</sub>&nbsp;+ SO<sub style="""">4</sub><sup style="""">2-</sup><sub style="""">(aq)</sub></i></div><div><br></div><div>K<sub>sp</sub>&nbsp;= <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">[Ba<sup>2+</sup>][SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2-</sup>]</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Solubility Product Constant.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/chemistry/acid-base-equilibrium/copy-of-solubility-equilibria-mcat/v/solubility-product-constant-from-the-solubility"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
<u>Q<sub>sp</sub></u>&nbsp;is the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""reaction&#x20;quotient"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> for a reaction that consists of a solid dissolving in a solution&nbsp;<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
    <u>Q<sub>sp</sub></u>&nbsp;is the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">reaction quotient</span> for a reaction that consists of a solid dissolving in a solution&nbsp;<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The reaction quotient for a regular chemical reaction is abbreviated Q<sub>c</sub></div><div><div><br></div><img src=""Qsp vs Ksp.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xly2k0UDTOo"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
If <u>Q<sub>sp</sub></u>&nbsp;is <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""less&#x20;than"" data-ordinal=""1"">[less than, greater than, or equal to]</span> K<sub>sp</sub> then the solution is unsaturated so no precipitate will form
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
    If <u>Q<sub>sp</sub></u>&nbsp;is <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">less than</span> K<sub>sp</sub> then the solution is unsaturated so no precipitate will form
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Qsp vs Ksp Saturation.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xly2k0UDTOo"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
If <u>Q<sub>sp</sub></u>&nbsp;is <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""equal&#x20;to"" data-ordinal=""1"">[less than, greater than, or equal to]</span> K<sub>sp</sub>&nbsp;then the solution is saturated and at equilibrium so no precipitate will form<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
    If <u>Q<sub>sp</sub></u>&nbsp;is <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">equal to</span> K<sub>sp</sub>&nbsp;then the solution is saturated and at equilibrium so no precipitate will form<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Qsp vs Ksp Saturation.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xly2k0UDTOo"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
If <u>Q<sub>sp</sub></u>&nbsp;is <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""greater&#x20;than"" data-ordinal=""1"">[less than, greater than, or equal to]</span> K<sub>sp</sub>&nbsp;then the solution is supersaturated so a precipitate will form<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
    If <u>Q<sub>sp</sub></u>&nbsp;is <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">greater than</span> K<sub>sp</sub>&nbsp;then the solution is supersaturated so a precipitate will form<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Qsp vs Ksp Saturation.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xly2k0UDTOo"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
The&nbsp;<b>common ion effect</b>&nbsp;causes solubility to <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""decrease"" data-ordinal=""1"">[increase or decrease]</span> when adding like ions<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions::Solubility</div>
    The&nbsp;<b>common ion effect</b>&nbsp;causes solubility to <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">decrease</span> when adding like ions<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Common Ion Effect.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/chemistry/acid-base-equilibrium/buffer-solutions/v/common-ion-effect"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions</div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Colligative properties</span> are physical properties of solutions that depend on the <b>concentration of dissolved particles</b> but not on their chemical identity</div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions</div>
<u>Raoult's law</u>&nbsp;states that the vapor pressure of a solution is equal to <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""the&#x20;sum&#x20;of&#x20;the&#x20;vapor&#x20;pressures&#x20;of&#x20;each&#x20;volatile&#x20;component&#x20;multiplied&#x20;by&#x20;the&#x20;mole&#x20;fraction&#x20;of&#x20;that&#x20;component&#x20;in&#x20;the&#x20;solution"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions</div>
    <u>Raoult's law</u>&nbsp;states that the vapor pressure of a solution is equal to <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">the sum of the vapor pressures of each volatile component multiplied by the mole fraction of that component in the solution</span><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>Raoult's law can&nbsp;be used to calculate the <b>molecular mass</b> of an unknown solute<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Raoult's Law.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VviZzYw7bK8"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Solutions</div>
    The presence of <i>nonvolatile</i> solute particles in a liquid solvent results in a/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">reduction</span> of the vapor pressure above a liquid

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations</div>
    <u>Weak</u> acids and bases have <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">weak</span> conjugates<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Conjugates.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/chemistry/acids-and-bases-topic/copy-of-acid-base-equilibria/v/conjugate-acid-base-pairs-acids-and-bases-chemistry-khan-academy"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations</div>
A<b>&nbsp;neutralization reaction</b>&nbsp;is when an acid and a base&nbsp;react&nbsp;to form <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""water"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> and <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""a&#x20;salt"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations</div>
    A<b>&nbsp;neutralization reaction</b>&nbsp;is when an acid and a base&nbsp;react&nbsp;to form <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">water</span> and <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">a salt</span><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>H<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;ions and OH<sup>-</sup>&nbsp;ions combine to generate water<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Neutralization Reaction (1).png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/chemistry/acids-and-bases-topic/copy-of-acid-base-equilibria/v/acid-base-properties-of-salts"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

<div>When [A<sup>-</sup>] = [HA] at the <b>half-equivalence point</b>, log(1) = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""0"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, so pH = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""pK&lt;sub&gt;a&lt;&#x2F;sub&gt;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::pH_and_pKa</div>
    <div>When [A<sup>-</sup>] = [HA] at the <b>half-equivalence point</b>, log(1) = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">0</span>, so pH = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">pK<sub>a</sub></span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Henderson 2.png""><div><br></div><div><img src=""Half Equivalence Point.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/chemistry/acid-base-equilibrium/buffer-solutions/v/buffers-and-hendersen-hasselbalch"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

The <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""half&#x2D;equivalence&#x20;point"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, also known as the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""midpoint"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, is the point of the buffering region, in which <i>half the titrant has been protonated or deprotonated</i>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Acids_and_Bases::Buffers_and_Titrations</div>
    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">half-equivalence point</span>, also known as the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">midpoint</span>, is the point of the buffering region, in which <i>half the titrant has been protonated or deprotonated</i>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">

A/an&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""concentration&#x20;cell"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;is an electrolytic&nbsp;cell&nbsp;that is comprised of two half-cells&nbsp;<b>with the</b> <b>same electrodes, but differing in&nbsp;concentrations</b><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Electrochemistry</div>
    A/an&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">concentration cell</span>&nbsp;is an electrolytic&nbsp;cell&nbsp;that is comprised of two half-cells&nbsp;<b>with the</b> <b>same electrodes, but differing in&nbsp;concentrations</b><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Concentration Cells.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aGdQ-6OS1iI"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Electrochemistry</div>
<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Reduction&#x20;potential"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is a measure of the tendency of a chemical species gain&nbsp;<b>electrons</b> and be reduced</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Electrochemistry</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Reduction potential</span> is a measure of the tendency of a chemical species gain&nbsp;<b>electrons</b> and be reduced</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>A more <i>positive E<sub>red</sub></i>&nbsp;indicates a greater tendency to be reduced</div><div><br></div><img src=""Reduction Potential.gif""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/chemistry/oxidation-reduction/cell-potential/v/standard-reduction-potentials"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::General_Chemistry::Electrochemistry</div>
The&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""standard&#x20;reduction&#x20;potential"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;is the <b>tendency for a chemical species to be reduced</b>, and is measured in volts at&nbsp;standard&nbsp;conditions<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Electrochemistry</div>
    The&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">standard reduction potential</span>&nbsp;is the <b>tendency for a chemical species to be reduced</b>, and is measured in volts at&nbsp;standard&nbsp;conditions<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Standard Reduction Potential 2.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""Standard Reduction Potentials.webp""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/chemistry/oxidation-reduction/cell-potential/v/standard-reduction-potentials"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">

The&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""electromotive&#x20;force&amp;nbsp&#x3B;&#x28;EMF&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the <i>maximum potential difference</i> between two electrodes of a galvanic or voltaic cell<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::General_Chemistry::Electrochemistry</div>
    The&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">electromotive force&nbsp;(EMF)</span> is the <i>maximum potential difference</i> between two electrodes of a galvanic or voltaic cell<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Also known as the <b>cell potential</b></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""EMF of a Cell.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k077CwKGiwk"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

    <img src=""Nernst Equation Blank.png""><div><br></div><div>Give the <u>Nernst equation</u>:<br><div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1""><img src=""Nernst Equation 1.png""></span></div></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The&nbsp;Nernst equation&nbsp;is used to calculate <b>cell potential in non-standard conditions</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>E<sub>cell</sub> = cell potential</div><div>Eº<sub>cell</sub>&nbsp;= standard cell potential<br></div><div>R =&nbsp;universal Gas Constant, 8.31&nbsp;\(\frac{J}{K•mol}\)</div><div>T = temperature in Kelvin<br></div><div>n = number of moles of electrons transferred<br></div><div>F = Faraday's constant = 96485&nbsp;\(\frac{C}{mol}\)<br></div><div>Q = reaction quotient (equals K if reaction is at equilibrium)</div><div><br></div><img src=""Nernst Equation.jpeg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/physical-processes/intro-electrochemistry-mcat/v/nerst-equation-edited"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The&nbsp;Nernst equation&nbsp;is used to calculate&nbsp;<b>cell potential in non-standard conditions</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>E<sub>cell</sub>&nbsp;= cell potential</div><div>Eº<sub>cell</sub>&nbsp;= standard cell potential<br></div><div>0.0592 = all constants multiplied or divided</div><div>n = number of moles of electrons transferred</div><div>Q = reaction quotient (equals K if reaction is at equilibrium)</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Nernst Equation 3.png""></div><div><br></div><img src=""Nernst Equation.jpeg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/physical-processes/intro-electrochemistry-mcat/v/nerst-equation-edited"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

<b>Very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) </b>are converted to <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""intermediate&#x2D;density&#x20;lipoproteins&#x20;&#x28;IDL&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> and then to <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""low&#x2D;density&#x20;lipoproteins&#x20;&#x28;LDL&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> before arriving at a tissue
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::Lipid_Metabolism</div>
    <b>Very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) </b>are converted to <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL)</span> and then to <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">low-density lipoproteins (LDL)</span> before arriving at a tissue
    <div>&nbsp;</div>

Give the formula used to calculate a person's <i>body mass index&nbsp;(BMI)</i>:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&#x5C;&#x28;&#x5C;frac&#x7B;weight&#x7E;in&#x7E;kg&#x7D;&#x7B;&#x28;height&#x7E;in&#x7E;meters&#x29;&#x5E;2&#x7D;&#x5C;&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Biochemistry::Metabolism</div>
    Give the formula used to calculate a person's <i>body mass index&nbsp;(BMI)</i>:<div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">\(\frac{weight~in~kg}{(height~in~meters)^2}\)</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Body Mass Index.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/healthcare-misc/v/calculate-your-own-body-mass-index"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    Describe the steps that make up the <u>scientific method</u>:<div><br></div><div><div>Initial steps: <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">formulate a hypothesis</span></div><div><br></div> <div>Intermediate steps: <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">test that hypothesis</span></div><div><br></div> <div>Final steps: <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">provide results for further testing of the hypothesis</span></div></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>

It asks, is the research <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""feasible"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""interesting"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""novel"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""ethical"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, and <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""relevant"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>?<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>

It asks, is the research <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">feasible</span>, <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">interesting</span>, <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">novel</span>, <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">ethical</span>, and <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">relevant</span>?<br>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
The ethics of clinical research requires <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""equipoise"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, which is a state of <b>genuine uncertainty</b> on the part of the clinical investigator regarding <u>which treatment is ""better"" </u>for the study participant<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    The ethics of clinical research requires <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">equipoise</span>, which is a state of <b>genuine uncertainty</b> on the part of the clinical investigator regarding <u>which treatment is ""better"" </u>for the study participant<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>Should the investigator discover that one treatment is of superior therapeutic merit, he or she is <i>ethically obliged to offer that treatment</i><br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Equipoise.jpg""><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Basic science research</span> <i>occurs in a lab</i> and does not include human subjects</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Basic science research is often the best type for demonstrating causality because the experimenter has the <i>highest degree of control</i> over the experimental conditions</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Basic Science Research.png""><br></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
A&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""positive&#x20;control"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... control]</span>&nbsp;is a group in an experiment that receives a treatment with a <i>known result</i>, and therefore should show a particular change during the experiment<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    A&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">positive control</span>&nbsp;is a group in an experiment that receives a treatment with a <i>known result</i>, and therefore should show a particular change during the experiment<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>It is used to&nbsp;control&nbsp;for unknown variables during the experiment and to give the scientist something to compare with the test group<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Positive Control.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZHTqxczEY6Y"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
A<b>&nbsp;</b><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""negative&#x20;control"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... control]</span><b>&nbsp;</b>group is a group in which <b>no response is expected</b><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    A<b>&nbsp;</b><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">negative control</span><b>&nbsp;</b>group is a group in which <b>no response is expected</b><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>It is the opposite of the positive&nbsp;control, in which a known response is expected<br></div><div><br></div><img src=""Negative Controls.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KXOvPVc6zeE"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Validity"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, also known as&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""accuracy"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>,&nbsp;is the degree to which the measurements of an experiment are <u>true and accurate</u><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Validity</span>, also known as&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">accuracy</span>,&nbsp;is the degree to which the measurements of an experiment are <u>true and accurate</u><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>This is <i>not</i> the same as<i> reliability</i>, which is the extent to which a measurement gives results that are very consistent<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Validity.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2fK1ClycBTM"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
When a scientist repeats an&nbsp;experiment&nbsp;with a different group of people or a different batch of the same chemicals and gets very <u>similar results</u> then those results are said to be&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""reliable"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> or <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""precise"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    When a scientist repeats an&nbsp;experiment&nbsp;with a different group of people or a different batch of the same chemicals and gets very <u>similar results</u> then those results are said to be&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">reliable</span> or <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">precise</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Validity.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2fK1ClycBTM"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>The&nbsp;sample&nbsp;should be representative of the population to ensure that we can generalize the findings from the&nbsp;research sample&nbsp;to the population as a whole<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Sample.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eIZD1BFfw8E"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">External validity</span> refers to the ability of a study to be <i>generalized</i> to the population that it describes

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""within&#x2D;subject&#x20;design"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... design]</span>&nbsp;is a type of experimental&nbsp;design&nbsp;in which <b>all participants are exposed to every treatment or condition</b><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">within-subject design</span>&nbsp;is a type of experimental&nbsp;design&nbsp;in which <b>all participants are exposed to every treatment or condition</b><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>The experiment controls for individual variations in a measurement by comparing the scores of a subject in one condition to the scores of the <i>same subject</i> in other conditions</div><div><br></div><div><u>So, the subject serves as its own control</u></div><div><u><br></u></div><div><img src=""Within Subject Design.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d-25eGNNCLg"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""between&#x2D;group&#x20;design"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... design]</span> is an experiment that has two or more groups of subjects each being <i>tested by a different testing factor simultaneously</i><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">between-group design</span> is an experiment that has two or more groups of subjects each being <i>tested by a different testing factor simultaneously</i><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Within Subject Design.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d-25eGNNCLg"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""case–control&#x20;study"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... study]</span> is a type of observational study in which <i>two existing groups </i>that differ in outcome are identified and compared on the basis of some supposed causal attribute<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    A/an <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">case–control study</span> is a type of observational study in which <i>two existing groups </i>that differ in outcome are identified and compared on the basis of some supposed causal attribute<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Case-Control Study.png""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=99FyAqwrIdI"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
The <b>Hill&nbsp;criteria</b>&nbsp;include the following 9 principles used to provide evidence of a causal relationship between a presumed cause and an observed effect:<br><div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Temporality"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Plausibility"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Consistency"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Strength&#x20;of&#x20;association"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Dose&#x20;response"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Reversibility"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Study&#x20;design"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Evidence"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    The <b>Hill&nbsp;criteria</b>&nbsp;include the following 9 principles used to provide evidence of a causal relationship between a presumed cause and an observed effect:<br><div><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Temporality</span><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Plausibility</span><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Consistency</span><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Strength of association</span><br></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Dose response</span></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Reversibility</span></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Study design</span></div><div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Evidence</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Hill Criteria.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-VFk-Pg6Yjo"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Selection bias</span>&nbsp;is the&nbsp;bias&nbsp;introduced by the&nbsp;selection&nbsp;of individuals, groups or data for analysis in such a way that <b>proper randomization is not achieved</b><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>The sample obtained is not representative of the population<div><br></div><div><img src=""Selection Bias.gif""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iSKerlu3Pr0"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

The <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""placebo&#x20;effect"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is a remarkable phenomenon in which a&nbsp;<i>placebo</i>&nbsp;-- a fake treatment, an inactive substance like sugar, distilled water, or saline solution -- can sometimes <i>improve a patient's condition</i> simply because the person has the expectation that it will be helpful.
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">

    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">placebo effect</span> is a remarkable phenomenon in which a&nbsp;<i>placebo</i>&nbsp;-- a fake treatment, an inactive substance like sugar, distilled water, or saline solution -- can sometimes <i>improve a patient's condition</i> simply because the person has the expectation that it will be helpful.

In a data set, the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""median"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the <b>middle number</b>; found by ordering all data points&nbsp;and&nbsp;picking out the&nbsp;one in the middle<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>
    In a data set, the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">median</span> is the <b>middle number</b>; found by ordering all data points&nbsp;and&nbsp;picking out the&nbsp;one in the middle<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>Or, if there are two middle numbers, take the mean of those two numbers<br></div><div><br></div><img src=""Mean Median Mode.png""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/math/statistics-probability/summarizing-quantitative-data/mean-median-basics/a/mean-median-and-mode-review"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>
<div>The&nbsp;<i>significance</i> of a statistical finding is determined by comparing the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""p&#x2D;value"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> to the selected</div> <div>significance level</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>
    <div>The&nbsp;<i>significance</i> of a statistical finding is determined by comparing the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">p-value</span> to the selected</div> <div>significance level</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>A significance level of 0.05 is commonly used</div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""p-Value Hypothesis Testing.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/math/statistics-probability/significance-tests-one-sample/idea-of-significance-tests/v/simple-hypothesis-testing"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>
    A&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">confidence interval</span>&nbsp;gives an estimated range of values which is likely to include an unknown population parameter<br>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Cognition::Problem_Solving MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>
If a medical test says someone has a disease, but the person actually <i>does not</i>, this is a type <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""1"" data-ordinal=""1"">[#]</span> error<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Cognition::Problem_Solving MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>
    If a medical test says someone has a disease, but the person actually <i>does not</i>, this is a type <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">1</span> error<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>Type 1 error = false positive<div><br></div><div><img src=""Type 1 and 2 Errors.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/math/ap-statistics/tests-significance-ap/error-probabilities-power/v/introduction-to-type-i-and-type-ii-errors"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::Behavioral::Cognition::Problem_Solving MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>
If a person <b>has a disease</b> but the medical test doesn't pick it up, this is a type <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""2"" data-ordinal=""1"">[#]</span> error<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::Behavioral::Cognition::Problem_Solving MileDown::Physics::Research::Data</div>
    If a person <b>has a disease</b> but the medical test doesn't pick it up, this is a type <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">2</span> error<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>Type 2 error = false negative<div><br></div><div><img src=""Type 1 and 2 Errors.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/math/ap-statistics/tests-significance-ap/error-probabilities-power/v/introduction-to-type-i-and-type-ii-errors"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Infrared</div>
<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Infrared&#x20;spectroscopy"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... spectroscopy]</span> measures absorption of infrared light, which causes <i>molecular vibration</i> such as stretching, bending, twisting, and folding</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Infrared</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Infrared spectroscopy</span> measures absorption of infrared light, which causes <i>molecular vibration</i> such as stretching, bending, twisting, and folding</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>Based on this it is possible to determine the functional groups that make up the molecule<div><br></div><div><div><u>Plotted as % transmittance vs. wavenumber (\(\frac{1}{λ}\))</u></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""IR Spectroscopy Vibrations.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""IR 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TmevMf-Zgs"">YouTube Link</a></div></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Ultraviolet&#x20;spectroscopy"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... spectroscopy]</span> measures the absorption of UV light, which causes <u>movement of electrons between molecular orbitals</u>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Ultraviolet spectroscopy</span> measures the absorption of UV light, which causes <u>movement of electrons between molecular orbitals</u>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>UV spectra are plotted as percent transmittance or absorbance vs. wavelength</div></div><div><br></div><img src=""Types of Spectroscopy.jpg""><div><br><div><img src=""UV Spectroscopy.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/spectroscopy-jay/uv-vis-spectroscopy/v/uv-vis-spectroscopy"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Nuclear&#x20;magnetic&#x20;resonance&#x20;spectroscopy"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... spectroscopy]</span> measures alignment of <b>nuclear spin</b> with an applied<i> magnetic field</i></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy</span> measures alignment of <b>nuclear spin</b> with an applied<i> magnetic field</i></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div>NMR spectroscopy is useful for determining the structure (connectivity) of a compound, including functional groups</div><div><br></div><div><div><u>Plotted as frequency vs. absorption energy</u></div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""NMR 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""NMR Shifts All.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SBir5wUS3Bo"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
<div>NMR spectra are <b>calibrated</b> using <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""tetramethylsilane&#x20;&#x28;TMS&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, which has a chemical shift of 0 ppm</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
    <div>NMR spectra are <b>calibrated</b> using <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">tetramethylsilane (TMS)</span>, which has a chemical shift of 0 ppm</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""TMS.png""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SBir5wUS3Bo"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
The <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""integration"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> is the area under each peak (signal) on the&nbsp;NMR&nbsp;spectrum. It corresponds to the <i>number of protons in that signal</i><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
    The <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">integration</span> is the area under each peak (signal) on the&nbsp;NMR&nbsp;spectrum. It corresponds to the <i>number of protons in that signal</i><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Integration 2 (3).png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Integration 1.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/spectroscopy-jay/proton-nmr/v/integration"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Deshielding"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> in NMR spectroscopy is when a nucleus' <i>chemical shift is increased</i> due to the removal of electron density, magnetic induction, or other effects<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Deshielding</span> in NMR spectroscopy is when a nucleus' <i>chemical shift is increased</i> due to the removal of electron density, magnetic induction, or other effects<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><b>Deshielding&nbsp;is the opposite of shielding</b><br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Deshielding 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Deshielding.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/spectroscopy-jay/proton-nmr/v/nuclear-shielding"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
In NMR spectroscopy, the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""chemical&#x20;shift"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;is the position on the δ scale (in ppm) <b>where the peak occurs</b><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
    In NMR spectroscopy, the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">chemical shift</span>&nbsp;is the position on the δ scale (in ppm) <b>where the peak occurs</b><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Deshielding.png""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Chemical Shifts 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/spectroscopy-jay/proton-nmr/v/chemical-shift"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
In NMR spectroscopy, a peak that is <u>deshielded</u> appears <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""downfield&#x20;&#x28;left&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[downfield or upfield]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
    In NMR spectroscopy, a peak that is <u>deshielded</u> appears <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">downfield (left)</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Chemical Shifts 2.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/spectroscopy-jay/proton-nmr/v/chemical-shift"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
In NMR spectroscopy, a peak that is <i>shielded</i> appears <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""upfield&#x20;&#x28;right&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[downfield or upfield]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
    <div>When hydrogens are on <b>adjacent</b> atoms, they interfere with each other’s magnetic environment, causing <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1""> spin-spin coupling</span> also known as <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">splitting</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Splitting.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/spectroscopy-jay/proton-nmr/v/spin-spin-splitting-coupling"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

<div>In NMR spectroscopy, the multiplicity of a proton or group of protons is given by the <b>n+1 rule</b>, where n = <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""the&#x20;number&#x20;of&#x20;protons&#x20;on&#x20;the&#x20;adjacent&#x20;&#x28;adjoining&#x29;&#x20;carbon&#x20;atom&#x20;&#x28;atoms&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::NMR</div>
    <div>In NMR spectroscopy, the multiplicity of a proton or group of protons is given by the <b>n+1 rule</b>, where n = <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">the number of protons on the adjacent (adjoining) carbon atom (atoms)</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""N plus 1.jpg""><div><br><div><img src=""n plus 1 3.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/science/organic-chemistry/spectroscopy-jay/proton-nmr/v/multiplicity-n-1-rule"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
A <u>mass spectrometer</u> ionizes atoms and molecules with a high-energy electron beam and then deflects the ions through a magnetic field based on the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""mass&#x2D;to&#x2D;charge&#x20;ratio&#x20;&#x28;&#x5C;&#x28;&#x5C;frac&#x7B;m&#x7D;&#x7B;z&#x7D;&#x5C;&#x29;&#x29;"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> of the ion<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
    A <u>mass spectrometer</u> ionizes atoms and molecules with a high-energy electron beam and then deflects the ions through a magnetic field based on the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">mass-to-charge ratio (\(\frac{m}{z}\))</span> of the ion<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>The mass spectrum of a sample shows <b>relative abundance of each ion on the y-axis</b> and&nbsp;<i>\(\frac{m}{z}\) along the x-axis</i><br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Mass Spectrum.png""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mBT73Pesiog"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
The largest peak in the mass spectrum, corresponding to the <i>most abundant ion</i>, is called the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""base&#x20;peak"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
    The largest peak in the mass spectrum, corresponding to the <i>most abundant ion</i>, is called the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">base peak</span><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Base Peak.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8YKhiG25lcg"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
In the mass spectrum, the <b>heaviest&nbsp;ion</b>&nbsp;(the one with the greatest m/z value) is likely to be the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""molecular&#x20;ion"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span><br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
    In the mass spectrum, the <b>heaviest&nbsp;ion</b>&nbsp;(the one with the greatest m/z value) is likely to be the&nbsp;<span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">molecular ion</span><br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""Molecular Ion Peak.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8YKhiG25lcg"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
In a mass spectrum, the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""M&#x2B;1"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> peak is a small peak&nbsp;<u>1 \(\frac{m}{z}\) unit to the right </u>of the main molecular ion peak
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
    In a mass spectrum, the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">M+1</span> peak is a small peak&nbsp;<u>1 \(\frac{m}{z}\) unit to the right </u>of the main molecular ion peak
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>The M+1 peak shows the <b>relative abundance of <sup>13</sup>C</b></div><div><br></div><div><sup style="""">13</sup>C<b>&nbsp;</b>is found in relative abundance of 1.1%</div><div><br></div><div>So, if M+1 has an&nbsp;\(\frac{m}{z}\) value of 4.4, that means there are 4 carbons since \(\frac{4.4}{1.1}\) = 4</div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""m plus 1.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8YKhiG25lcg"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
In a mass spectrum, the <i>M+2 peak</i> shows the relative abundance of either <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&lt;sup&gt;81&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;Br"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>&nbsp;or <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""&lt;sup&gt;37&lt;&#x2F;sup&gt;Cl"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
    In a mass spectrum, the <i>M+2 peak</i> shows the relative abundance of either <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1""><sup>81</sup>Br</span>&nbsp;or <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1""><sup>37</sup>Cl</span>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div><u>Br has a 1:1 ratio relative to the M peak</u></div><div><u><br></u></div> <div><b>Cl has a 3:1 ratio relative to the M peak</b></div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""m + 2 Br.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""M plus 2 Cl.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8YKhiG25lcg"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
In a mass spectrum:<div><br></div><div><div>Br has a <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""1&#x3A;1"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> ratio relative to the M peak</div><div><br></div><div>Cl has a <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""3&#x3A;1"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> ratio relative to the M peak</div></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy MileDown::OChem::Spectroscopy::Mass_Spectrometry</div>
    In a mass spectrum:<div><br></div><div><div>Br has a <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">1:1</span> ratio relative to the M peak</div><div><br></div><div>Cl has a <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">3:1</span> ratio relative to the M peak</div></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><img src=""m + 2 Br.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""M plus 2 Cl.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8YKhiG25lcg"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
    <div>In an extraction, the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">nonpolar</span> layer is the organic layer and dissolves nonpolar compounds</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Extraction.png""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/chemical-processes/separations-purifications/v/extractions"">Khan Academy Link</a></div></div>

"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
In an extraction, the <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""polar"" data-ordinal=""1"">[polar or nonpolar]</span> layer is the aqueous (water) layer and dissolves compounds with hydrogen bonding or polarity
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
    In an extraction, the <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">polar</span> layer is the aqueous (water) layer and dissolves compounds with hydrogen bonding or polarity

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
<span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""Recrystallization"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, also known as <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""fractional&#x20;crystallization"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span>, is a procedure for purifying an impure compound in a solvent<br>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
    <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">Recrystallization</span>, also known as <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">fractional crystallization</span>, is a procedure for purifying an impure compound in a solvent<br>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>An impure compound is dissolved to prepare a highly concentrated solution at a high temperature<div><br></div><div>The solution is cooled</div><div><br></div><div>Decreasing the temperature causes the solubility of the impurities in the solution and the substance being purified to decrease</div><div><br></div><div><b>The impure substance then crystallizes before the impurities</b>- assuming that there was more impure substance than there were impurities<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Recrystallization.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Recrystallization 2.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=htTvL4JhscM"">YouTube Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
<div><b>Chromatography</b> is a laboratory technique for the separation of a mixture based on <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""how&#x20;fast&#x20;each&#x20;component&#x20;travels&#x20;through&#x20;a&#x20;structure"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span></div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
    <div><b>Chromatography</b> is a laboratory technique for the separation of a mixture based on <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">how fast each component travels through a structure</span></div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'>The mixture is dissolved in a fluid called the <u>mobile phase</u>, which carries it through a structure holding another material called the <i>stationary phase</i><div><br></div><div>The various constituents of the mixture travel at <b>different speeds</b>, causing them to separate<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Chromatography.gif""></div><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/chemical-processes/separations-purifications/v/basics-of-chromatography"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">
<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
In chromatography, the stationary phase is typically <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""polar"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> and this causes <span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""polar"" data-ordinal=""1"">[...]</span> molecules to elute slower
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
    In chromatography, the stationary phase is typically <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">polar</span> and this causes <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">polar</span> molecules to elute slower
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Mobile vs Stationary Phases.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/chemical-processes/separations-purifications/v/basics-of-chromatography"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>
</div>"
"<div id=""kard"">

</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>

    <div>&nbsp;</div>

    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
    <div>In liquid chromatography, <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">silica</span> is a common stationary phase while <span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">toluene</span> or another nonpolar liquid is used as the mobile phase</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><img src=""Liquid Chromatography.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/chemical-processes/separations-purifications/v/basics-of-chromatography"">Khan Academy Link</a><br></div></div>

<div class=""tags"">MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
<div><span class=""cloze"" data-cloze=""High&#x2D;performance&#x20;liquid&#x20;chromatography"" data-ordinal=""1"">[... chromatography]</span> relies on pumps to pass a <u>pressurized liquid solvent</u> containing the sample mixture through a column filled with a solid adsorbent material</div>
</div>"	"<div id=""kard"">
    <div class=""tags"" id='tags'>MileDown::OChem::Separations</div>
    <div><span class=""cloze"" data-ordinal=""1"">High-performance liquid chromatography</span> relies on pumps to pass a <u>pressurized liquid solvent</u> containing the sample mixture through a column filled with a solid adsorbent material</div>
    <div>&nbsp;</div>
    <div id='extra'><div><div>This gives HPLC <b>higher resolving power</b></div></div><div><br></div><img src=""HPLC.jpg""><div><br></div><div><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kz_egMtdnL4"">YouTube Link</a></div></div>
